review_body: Consistent service with my past Aman hotel experiences. Loved the amazing city views from our room and the convenient location. The hotel is beautifully designed inside and out. Can’t wait to come back again to try the sushi restaurant and go for another dip in the pool.

Stayed for 3 days and everything at Aman is perfect. The hotel is exquisite. The staff are amazing, top notch service. The architecture really is incredible. I must say beautiful in all aspects. Wish we could stay longer.

Although I live in Tokyo but I decided to take a break to stay in a hotel for the weekend because I haven't swum in the pool for months so I picked AMAN because I wanted to try their pool for a long time.I love the hotel lobby area. The high ceiling design is just so beautiful. Checking-in on a Sunday afternoon, the hotel looks like full of people in the lobby lounge having strawberries sweets. It was kind of loud and felt the hotel has become very commercial like other hotels in Japan trying to bring customers in with special promotion. When they first opened, the restaurant and lounge were more quite and relax.Anyhow I checked into my deluxe room. It was very spacious, much nicer than I expected. Very modern style Japanese which I liked. Long lounge chair, king size bed and a big bath tub. Then I went straight to the pool and swam for an hour. The pool was nice as expected. But they didn't have any magazines to read which was disappointed to be in the day bed. The pool was empty which was good for me. I also tried their o-furo (big Japanese bath area) also quite nice.At night, I didn't want to sleep yet so I went down to the bar and this is where the biggest disappointment came in. Although the afternoon crowd was gone, the bar was quite but the bartender wasn't friendly at all. I order a glass of wine, i guess he got pissed off that I didn't like the taste of it and asked for another one. When he was making a cocktail, I said to him that it looks good, he just returned with a bitter smile. A normal person will say what he is making or tried to talk to a customer when she si alone. Then I heard him using language to his colleague that it was not something a customers should hear. Anyhow, i took my wine and left because I didn't feel I was welcomed there. Hotel Amenities: No brand name items but the smell of the products were good.They should put an espresso machine or tea set in the room. Overall: Hotel ★★★★Design ★★★★★Service ★★★Cleanliness ★★★★★Location ★★★★

An outstanding stay in a beautiful Aman in downtown Tokyo. Absolutely fabulous from check-in to check-out and the service was superb: the usual out- of- this-world Aman standards. The view from the suite with two rooms was pretty stellar and the interior decoration personified classic and modern Japan to perfection . I could stay here forever! Very very classy and with that profound Japanese aesthetic of understated elegance at play everywhere in the decor. Totally fell in love with the place. Arguably the best hotel room/suite in Tokyo and very close by the Imperial Palace. A stay here is a once- in- a lifetime experience not to be missed.

Stayed here for 2 nights (second time after 3 years). Service is top notch. Not cheap but you get what you pay for - big luxurious room, full facilities, top notch service, excellent staff, and more. Location is not the best for me (I would have preferred it closer to Tokyo station) but it is convenient enough for a 5 star rating.

We stayed at Aman Tokyo in Dec 2018 for a couple nights. I love the hotel’s architecture. The lobby’s high ceiling is really gorgeous and and the room is very well designed and spacious. They provide an apple for your hot bath in the room which is very unique. Breakfast was pretty good. We tried the massage and it was expensive but just ok. The only complaint I had was the unfriendly receptionist when we check in and out. I can tell they treat people differently especially if you are not Japanese which is unacceptable for hotel that charge for more than USD 1,000/night.

I have stayed at several urban five-star hotels (Park Hyatt New York, Four Seasons New York, Miami and Denver, Mandarin Oriental New York, St. Regis D.C., as far as I can recall) and Aman Tokyo is by far the best. The room is huge and beautifully furnished. The service is better than most Four Seasons (although I do love the staff at the New York downtown FS). The gym and the pool are sizable and offer unrivaled views. The only thing that was kind of just 'ok' is the breakfast.

Tokyo definitely is one of the most interesting city in the world ! There’s a plenty of hotels but Aman far away is the best one ! Exclusive and high quality service, amenities and staff. It’s pretty well located (close by Ginza and parks). Amazing experience and for sure intend to get back !

The most impressive Amans are probably not in urban centers, so we were apprehensive. It turned out to be a best in class experience. The architecture and interior design are spectacular, the exercise facility and pool on the 34th floor are impressive and the breakfasts were top notch. Customer service is as good as it gets.The panoramic windows in the rooms and bathroom afford great views of Tokyo and one night we were fortunate to see fireworks at a distance.Overall it is well worth the four digit rates.

Beautiful in all aspects, restaurant, great view from bar, lobby, shop, reception. We had great lunch, bento box and tempura. Beautiful presentation. Live music in lobby. Great location to unwind. Enjoyed the perfect hospitality.

We stayed 2 nights on the 37th floor of the Aman Tokyo in November 2019. The hotel and staff are spectacular. The hotel is an oasis of tranquility from its design, mix of wood/stone/water/space to the calm peaceful nature and pace of its staff and operations. This is not a hotel for those in a rush - expect to spend 90 minutes having a delicious and well-rounded breakfast for instance. Although in the top floors of an office building, the interior is breathtaking with a lobby that has a height of at least 3 stories. Rooms and bathrooms are luxurious with superb views of Tokyo through wall to ceiling windows and remote controlled blinds. The pool, spa, and even the exercise rooms are also set in quiet peaceful environments and all equipped/furnished with like-new equipment. This is a place to escape to for the mind and body. Perhaps the many business oriented clients we observed there knew this and stayed there to lower the stress of a busy day.

Our first visit to aman hotel , we are in love and will continue to visit aman all around the world . Everything were perfect , simple and great . Very warm service Less is more . Thank you introduced the best for us .

I have stayed in different hotels in Tokyo and Aman (as usual) is so far the best one. The staff has eye for detail, they are attentive and kind.The facilities are incredibly confortable, luxurious and zen - the place has an incredible good energy ! Also, it is important to mention that my experience was improved thanks to Asako - she is sincerely kind, friendly, efficient and made me feel like home. She is one of the best hotel employees that I have ever met in my whole life (and well, I can say I have already met so so many...) . Ps. If you are staying at Aman Tokyo, please, enjoy the great view from the pool (the greatest in Tokyo).

Everything about the hotel was perfect. The lobby design was a refreshing sanctuary after a very long flight. Even when the lobby was busy it never seemed hectic...there was always a quiet hush about it. The layout of the regular room had more than ample space. As someone who nearly always books a suite, I don’t think it was necessary. If possible, get a room with a view of gardens. Waking up that each morning just makes you smile. The bed was a little hard for my liking but the wife loved it. Breakfast in the morning was a highlight. There were plenty of options and everything we had was completed with the highest level of attention. We very much enjoyed the staff as well. The concierge had great recommendations arranging dinners and a tour. Front desk, dining and bellmen were great as well. Enjoyed them being fluent in English as well. It would be very difficult to find a single negative thing to say about the experience. It pressed, the location is a bit corporate but we knew that going into it. It’s close to the train station so getting around Tokyo was easy.

Bit of a bold title but from staying in many luxury hotels on my trip to Japan, we decided to try The Aman for our last part of the trip and our second stay in Tokyo. The service is exemplary throughout Japan and we found the Aman to be even better. The hotel is of course beautifully designed with the most stunning swimming pool with breathtaking views - if you cant swim learn before you go - you wont be disappointed ! The bedroom was superb, spacious , zen like and tastefully appointed . The black stone bathroom was a joy to use . This was 'just' a standard room , honestly one of the best ive ever stayed in anywhere. Expensive yes, but the best always is .

Aman Tokyo is located in the heart of Tokyos business district.While this can technically be considered a business hotel, the moment you enter the lobby you feel a sense of zen.You totally escape the hustle and bustle of toyko and you are treated to this serene lobby.The rooms a simple but yet elegant, very "Japanese" in design, which I very much enjoyed. The hotel welcome amenity for us was the Japanese musk melon, my absolute favorite. Service at this hotel is what you would expect from a top end 5 star hotel in Tokyo, professional, courteous, and with a hint of that Aman magic. I highly recommend the Rickshaw tour arranged by the hotel, what a great way to see the city, and the guide spoke perfect English, was funny and super engaging.The team did a good job anticipating our needs, especially during departure when we almost missed our train, and the team pulled out all the stops to make sure we got to our train on time.Hotel manager Kenji, was very personable, and offered that personal touch that really made this stay extra special.Definitely my favorite hotel in Tokyo

This hotel is breathtaking. From the grand lobby, to the spa, pool, and the amazing view from our large room. The entire staff is incredible - the service was by far the best I have experienced in any hotel in the world. This will be the only hotel I will consider staying at when I return to Tokyo.

Where do I start - this hotel has perhaps the best service I have had in any hotel I have stayed in - an accolade I never previously awarded to any hotel as none has impressed me so profoundly as here.The Kerry Hill-directed minimalism is utterly blissful - nothing comparable in Tokyo, especially the pool which IMO is the best of any city hotel in the world.The rooms are also fabulous but only come here if you are a fan of minimalism as this is the theme throughout the hotel, especially in the rooms - they are also however the biggest entry-level rooms in Tokyo at 70msq.I am frankly disgusted by the numerous 1 star reviews of this hotel which fail to encompass the above-and-beyond staff and what this hotel has to offer and instead go on to make a complaint regarding a hilariously trivial issue, as is the case with many fantastic hotels I have stayed in - it almost seems as they are here to purposefully hinder the hotel.Bottom line - come here if you want the best service, location, pool and the biggest entry-level rooms in Tokyo (and ignore the 1 star reviews)

This hotels is simply spectacular. There is not a bad thing to be said about this hotel. It simply has a way of making you feel special from the moment you check in to the time you check out. The service was superb and the room was incredible. Every other hotel we have stayed at, while nice, did not leave the lasting feeling that this hotel did. If you’re looking for the best place to stay while in Tokyo, the answer is easy... this is the place.

Been here twice and its the best!We have been visiting Japan twice and both times stayed at Aman Tokyo. The level of service is so good! The hotel is nice and very zen like - just whay you need when you finish a day of exploring tokyo

Unfortunately, I could be a victim of expecting too much from the AMAN brand. Was relatively disappointed as services was not as personal and lack of attention to details comparing with Hoshinoya Tokyo and The Prince Gallery Kioicho.Check in was a bit messy as there were dinning guests and the check in staff got confused with and the diner at the lift entrance on the 33rd and I walked over myself to the counter and they were a bit confused too.There wasn’t any explanation on the facilities or highlights like the fame ceiling where I actually read in other people blog. Was lost at the 34rd floor SPA and the staff only give pointing instructions.Lastly, the dinner reservations which was made via their concierge was not picked up and was asked to come down to 33rd floor and there will be staffs attending me during dinner which in fact, it is on the 34rd floor.The room is excellent though, picture perfect. However, service is not personal enough for the price.The Japanese restaurant Musashi is excellent!

This is one of The Best Hotels we’ve stayed at. The service here was fantastic, everyone in Japan is super polite, sweet and serviceable but the staff here went above the standard. Our room was the size of an apartment and decorated impeccably. We had a corner suite, with floor to ceiling windows overlooking the entire city which was jaw dropping. The kitchen, dining room, living room, office and guest bathroom were the cherry on the cake. Our room and bathroom alone were the size of a large NYC apartment. All in light wood and dark stone, it really gave you the less is more Japanese feel, in a very contemporary and classy way. The food: breakfast and dinner at the Italian restaurant were wonderful but the kicker was the Sushi restaurant which was a hidden gem (you had to walk on stepping stones to get there). We wholeaheartedly did not want to leave the city and especially the hotel. It is breathtaking the minute you walk into the Lobby. And I can only dream of owning an apartment just like our room in a beautiful big city! Thank you Aman for a beautiful experience!

Visited this hotel for 4 nights in early July .The hotel is ideally located just above the Otemachi train station and about 10 minutes walk to the Tokyo JR station.Our room is located on 37th floor with a beautiful palace view and an onsen bath right next to a floor to ceiling window.We visited the spa every morning and we received warm welcome from the staffs everyday. Inside the locker room you can find an onsen bath ( similar to the one in FS in Seoul but a little smaller ) with a steam room right next to it.The swimming pool has a stunning view of the city and you can actually do lap swimming. We really enjoyed the tranquility and peacefulness of the pool.We ate breakfast everyday at the Arva and the Japanese breakfast was not only delicious but also beautifully presented. The staffs even recognized our food preferences and allergies.Overall what make this hotel standout is the staff and the minimalistic design. It looks like a very modern hotel but it also feels like a warm traditional Japanese hotel. Even though this maybe the most expensive hotel in Tokyo but this is also the best hotel in Tokyo.

I wanted to start this review for thanking the staff for being the loveliest people you can come across. They organised everything for my travel and as i was travelling on the train to the airport they accompanied me making sure i get the right train given the complicated main station. It wasn’t needed but they wouldn’t take no for an answer. Hotel is just brilliant. Sexy, yet so comfortable rooms, great views, food and drinks were excellent, lovely locations and close to many attractions and also it is near the metro so few stops and you’re in central Tokyo or you can be wherever you want to be visiting many interesting locations the city can offer. I am the gym and fitness enthusiast and their gym is just perfect. Plus you can check your body composition there for free because they have the most accurate machine installed in the gym. Thanks for the perfect 4 days I had with you. M x

We stayed at the Aman Tokyo’s for three nights last month and everything was amazing. When we checked in we were told that we would not need a reservation for dinner after a long flight. Later that evening we arrived to a packed restaurant with nothing available. The manager, Imre, set us up in our own private dinning area with private service. The meal was great and so was the rest of our stay. The pool is 30 floors up and over looks the city. The hotel is beautiful and the staff and service is excellent. Definitely a five star hotel.

Hands down the BEST hotel I have ever stayed at. I stayed at the Aman for four nights and the experience was flawless from start to finish. Location: Aman Tokyo is located at the top of the Otemachi tower; the Otemachi Tokyo Metro station conveniently located in the building, with access to 5-6 metro lines. Room: Beautiful and spacious (probably the largest hotel room you'll find in all of Tokyo); it felt like an oasis. The bed overlooks a floor-to-ceiling window, with stunning views of the city. The room also has a nice lounging and dining area. The bathroom is spacious, beautifully designed, and also comes with a view. Service: Impeccable, as expected. Every detail is taken care of, and the staff are so polite and meticulous. Concierge was very helpful with dinner reservations. Facilities: Despite the Aman being a small hotel, the facilities were top notch! The gym was large and well-equipped. The pool was the most beautiful pool I've ever swam in. 30 meters long, views of the city from the 34th floor, cavernous ceilings. If anything, come to Aman just for the pool! I did not indulge in any spa services, but guests are welcome to hang out in the ladies & mens changing areas, which feature onsen-style hot tubs and a sauna. The Aman Tokyo is the standard by which I will judge other luxury hotels going forward - it was simply perfect.

review_body: This was our first stay at an Aman property, and I have to say it was impressive. In the maelstrom that is Tokyo (our first visit), the Aman is an oasis of calm. Room was lovely, and the design is an excellent combination of Japanese style and western design. Great views over the city. What really sets the place apart from other high-end properties is the intimate size (while retaining all of the big hotel amenities) and the personal service. The concierge staff was unbelievable in the months leading up to our stay; extraordinarily responsive and helpful and organized (by contrast, just getting a response from the concierge staff at the Four Seasons Kyoto -- nearly as pricy -- was like pulling teeth). It's impossible to call a hotel at this price a "value," but it was a really great stay.

Was here last December for business and must say this hotel is extraordinary. First time with Aman hotels and was a nice experience. Very thoughtful rooms and delicious breakfast spreadout. True 5 star

Extraordinary hotel, we loved every minute here. The public spaces are huge, comfortable and beautiful. The room was so nicely thought out, Aman clean lines and minimalism, but still very comfortable. Lovely bathroom, we really enjoyed the stone onsen style deep bath with amazing views over the Palace. We loved how quiet it was, we never ever heard anyone else in the corridor. (Which always smelt of lemongrass, how do they do that! ) . And the views from the bedroom windows....... amazing. We have stayed at Amans before, all very nice and comfortable. This one is is on a higher level. The staff are extraordinary, charming, helpful and nothing is too much trouble. We enjoyed a meal in the restaurant , one in the bar lounge and breakfasts. All were top quality and very enjoyable, we really do like a served breakfast rather than the buffet element. Much more relaxing.Absolutely no negatives, we would certainly want to stay again if we are in Tokyo again. Just sorry our stay was so short. Wonderful stay, thanks to all the lovely staff!

I stayed at Aman Tokyo with my wife for two nights during a recent trip to Japan. We had a great stay, and we thoroughly enjoyed the hotel. Service and room quality are the typical Aman "above and beyond" standard. The hotel and the rooms are beautiful. We enjoyed a meal at the hotel's sushi restaurant. It would be very difficult for us to stay anywhere else on future trips to Tokyo. Thank you!

In my opinion the best hotel in the world The design has no parallel with any other place They really captured the Japanese minimalism in the most sophisticated way. The service is impeccable The food the best than you can get and the concierge service absolutely amazing. The Aman Tokyo is worth every penny . The rooms the open shower where you can see trough a big window The immensity of this city An unforgettable experience

We walked into the Aman after a long flight and we were just wowed. Our view looked out to Mt. Fuji....and over the Imperial Palace.......and it felt like we were floating on air. I loved the whole look of the hotel from the height of the lobby ceiling to the clean lines of our room.  In a city as busy and crowded as Tokyo ...the Aman hotel was the perfect escape....a real serene oasis . I actually had a hard time even leaving the hotel to go out.....it was so inviting and relaxing that I just wanted to hang out and enjoy it. The hotel checked all the boxes in so many ways......cleaniless, cool bar and lobby, good food at the Italian restaurant , nice spa , fantastic views from our room, a very comfortable bed. .....etc... But, there was something missing that I have to mention if order for this to be an even better hotel. The missing link....was the concierge . We were really surprised at how little information they gave us when we went to get some help. We have travelled all over the world at the best hotels and always found the concierge to be top notch. There were three people working the concierge table and yet none were able to give us much help on questions about train travel, shopping, or restaurants. We were sent to a restaurant and not told that it was on a second floor......no signs written in English .....and it took us an extra 20 minutes to even find it. . No one explained much about the train to Kyoto and since there is not anything written in English it is important that the guests at the Aman be able to get more information from the concierges. The concierges at the Aman need a lot more training.....we stayed a the Peninsula too and their concierges were first rate. If the Aman could fix this issue....they could have one of the most incredible city hotels in Asia. And, there was one other small issue but it needs to be addressed too....the staff in the restaurants were nice ; but very slow even when the restaurant was almost empty. We asked for water three times and waited ten minutes for it to be brought to the table....both at dinner and at breakfast....it was almost comical; but not right for such a high end hotel. I don't usually write anything negative;but I truly loved this hotel and would like these problems to be fixed to make it really as high end as it looks.... great service is important.

I really enjoyed the stay at the Aman Tokyo. It is not only a very warm and stylish place, nice rooms and great ambience. Also the team there, the people and the hotel crew were extraordinarily caring, friendly and warm.

We had an incredible 1 night stay as our last day in Tokyo. The atmosphere is magnificent and the service is over the top amazing. The view of Tokyo from around the hotel is awesome and made us glad we didn’t bother going to the Tokyo SkyTree as I imagine the view is similar. The hotel got us into Sukiyabashi Jiro for lunch and drove us there for free. We also got a complimentary transfer to the Tokyo station and escorted all the way to the Narita express JR train by Yui and Yuri, who were absolutely wonderful and so friendly. They do everything they can to earn the high cost to make your stay as simple and convenient as possible.

The hotel was a lovely end to our two week trip in Japan. The pool was incredible on the 34th floor and had amazing views. The hotel restaurant (Avra) was very delicious with generous portions. The gentleman that helped us choose our wine and food dishes was very accommodating and friendly. The room was spacious and had a stunning view.

My wife had an art exhibition of her work in Tokyo and ask me to join her. I have been before to Amanaya at Turks and Caicos but the Aman Tokyo was above my expectations for sure. The service is stupendous, the food is rooted in local tradition (if you want the local stuff) and the facilities are breathtaking.It is worth the price for sure.Location is very good with walking distance for many sightseeing places, the palace as well.

We got off a long flight and headed for the spa. Incredible. The pool is one of the coolest thing you will see in a hotel. The rooms are large and perfect. The service is Aman.

In December 2018, I checked into the Premier Room at Aman Tokyo, the first urban outpost from the widely-acclaimed ultra-luxury hotel brand known for its remote and exotic Asian resorts. Situated on levels 33-38 of Otemachi Tower in Tokyo's financial district and minutes away from both Otemachi and Tokyo Station, the 84-room hotel brands itself as a sanctuary and a serene escape from the bustle of the metropolis, and you could not find descriptors more apt.I made this booking under Mr & Mrs Smith and was entitled to breakfast for two at Arva, the hotel's Italian restaurant, as a Smith Extra.AMAN TOKYOAs you exit the elevator on the 33rd floor, you are greeted by an unforgettable, breathtaking visual: a 30-metre tall "lantern" - a hollow roof wallpapered with seemingly glowing white washi paper rising six floors through the centre of the lobby atrium - suspends over a zen garden comprising a seasonal ikebana flower arrangement (during my winter visit, the floral centrepiece played it all Tilda Swinton in its glacial drama) in the middle of a water pond along with two rock gardens.The very minimalist proceedings limits itself to Japanese traditional textures of wood, paper and stone. A lady in a kimono, seated along a verandah-like raised walkway, plays the koto (Japanese zither) with a sense of affected urgency. Tall partitions loosely separate the dining concepts on the lobby level - Italian concept Arva as well as the hotel's Lounge and Bar - which are all gloriously illuminated by floor-to-ceiling windows with spectacular views of the Tokyo skyline.The cold stone walls, impossibly high ceilings and ethereal grandeur of the lobby experience alone makes the premises feel like the celestial fortress of a demi-god rather than simply ultra-luxurious accommodation for mere mortals like myself.Other concepts on the lobby floor include cigar lounge Fumoir as well as the hotel's Boutique, which stocks both partner retail products as well as Aman-branded merchandise and selections from the Aman skincare range.PREMIER ROOMThe airy and spacious 80sqm Premier Room plays it all traditional Japanese home meets rustic ryokan inn, with light woods, sliding shoji doors, earthy ceramics and traditional calligraphy. (Do not mistake the quaint proceedings for backwardness - a hidden flatscreen TV emerges from the table-top at the press of a remote control button like magic, and the room is equipped with a Bose sound system as well as controls for your lights, blinds and curtains.) The king-sized bed directly faces the floor-to-ceiling windows, which present a panoramic view of Tokyo Skytree and the East Tokyo skyline. Steps on both sides of the bed lead down to the minibar, a dining table and a window-side daybed which is perfect for red wine-fuelled and pensive Lost in Translation-esque moments staring into the red and white light-specked distance after night falls.The mini-bar stocks canned beverages, wines and juices as well as bottles of traditional Japanese crackers. Tea and coffee-making facilities, as well as a Nespresso coffee machine, are also available.One of the Premier Room’s key features is its traditional stone bath, which is modelled after the traditional Japanese furo deep-soak bath. The bath experience comes equipped with generous quantities of woody - almost whisky-esque - Japanese cypress bath salts as well as a paper manual with instructions on bathing and Japanese bathing etiquette (“Disrobe...rinse your body, start with the feet and shins, then onto your legs…”). The hot bath is intended for warmth, relaxation, improving blood circulation as well as healing the body from tension and fatigue. Any soaping and removal of shameful bodily filth is meant to be done separately, using either the Oke wood bucket whilst sitting naked on a stool or the available modern shower facilities, with double vanities and Aman’s house range of bath amenities at your disposal.As the hotel was informed prior to my arrival that my stay coincides with my birthday week, the staff thoughtfully prepared for me a platter of chocolates as well as a bottle of red wine for the occasion.WELLNESS AND AMAN SPAThe 2,500sqm zen-like Aman Spa spans two entire floors, comprising a Japanese bath, steam room and eight treatment rooms. Their signature treatments, ranging from body scrubs and acupressure facials to hot stone massages and herbal foot baths, incorporate kampo (Japanese traditional medicine), seasonal herbs and local oils.On the wellness front, guests have access to a fitness centre, yoga and pilates studios, changing rooms with steam rooms and a traditional onsen-style stone bath, as well as a sleek 30-metre indoor pool, most of which offer breathtaking views of urban Tokyo.The swimming pool is all sorts of magnificent, resembling a celestial fortress of a demi-god in the day and transforming into a futuristic J-RPG final boss dungeon at night, with the formidably soaring pillars seemingly penetrating the white heavenly skies above. I was advised by the staff that a magical glimpse of Mt. Fuji might be possible from the pool at 6.30am every morning if the skies feel particularly charitable that day.Elsewhere, unlike international business hotels like Conrad Tokyo, the hotel is firm about its onsen nudity policies, so I had to strip away all modesties before I could revel in the red-faced, sweaty and deep breathing aquatic proceedings. Fortunately, like your in-room Japanese furo deep-soak bath, there are shower stalls available post-onsen such that it is not necessary to go through the (very public) traditional bucket-and-stool bathing ritual.DININGBreakfast at the hotel is served at Arva, the Italian restaurant on the lobby floor which plays it all clean-lined wood partitions and magnificent floor-to-ceiling windows which extend beyond 98 feet in height. Guests can opt for either a traditional Japanese breakfast (think baked seasonal fish, Japanese rolled omelet with grated radish, marinated seasonal vegetable and steamed rice or congee, with seasonal fruit) or an American-style breakfast comprising your choice of three pieces of side meat (I opted for crispy bacon, black pepper bacon and Canadian bacon) along with a bread basket and fruit plate. Arva prides itself on its use of locally-sourced ingredients rooted in Italian family-style techniques, and sample offerings include wild boar ragout with truffle, grilled barracuda with roasted cauliflower and anchovy, ravioli with sparkling enope squid (i.e. firefly squid) with fava beans.Just next door is the Lounge by Aman, the hotel's lounge and bar which overlooks the Imperial Palace Gardens. The lounge is a popular destination for their picturesque Black Afternoon Tea, which dramatically juxtaposes the lounge's monochromatic sensibilities with the bright, eye-popping colours of the sweet and savoury afternoon tea offerings - think berry and plain scones, mixed berry soup with champagne espuma, truffle quiche, celeriac mont blanc, snow crab sandwich, chicken fricassée, colourful petit sweets (your choice of four from a selection presented within a travel trunk) and a Christmas Ball encasing pastille surprises. Not since Peacock Alley at Waldorf Astoria Bangkok has an afternoon tea experience so tantalised my senses, both visual and gustatory.The adjacent Bar area sees mixologists serving tipples with a decidedly Japanese slant. Bar counter seats directly face the Tokyo skyline, and the glorious view is best exploited in the evening when guests can partake in confessional whispers over seasonal cocktails - I have come across both strawberry as well as black-themed cocktail menus - while appreciating the splendid transitional sunset experience. Savoury bites are also available for the peckish.Located on the ground floor, The Café by Aman offers casual French cuisine by an "Otemachi Forest" lush setting at the base of the office tower, while the latest concept to join the property, Musashi by Aman, serves exquisite sushi over a Hinoki wooden counter.CONCLUDING THOUGHTSThe hotel offers a revelatory, game-changing, ultra-luxurious sanctuary experience which would likely redefine and recalibrate one's expectations towards luxury hotel accommodation. I simply cannot wait to experience another Aman property.

I'm a regular traveller to Japan for family holiday and have stayed at many hotel around Tokyo. All of them provides great customer service but AMAN Tokyo was one step above the rest. First the lobby was huge and has one of the best design I have seen. High ceiling made out of Washi paper was a highlight. The room we stayed at was on 36th floor and we can see Mt Fuji from the floor to ceiling windows and it was a delight. As was the in room tub.But the most impressive thing about AMAN is not the decor or the rooms. It's the people that makes the biggest difference. I was serviced but a lovely lady named Miki Inayoshi. She was so polite and helpful with every need my family has requested. The most amazing about her customer care skills was when we left the hotel and arrived back home in Sydney. We realised that we left a pair of snow shoes we have purchased at a Shibuya ramen restaurant. We called Miki and she contacted the restaurant and got the new shoes from them. With the assistance of Tomoko Yagi (General Manager AMAN Tokyo) they sent it to my home in Sydney. NOW that's service at the highest level. I thank both Miki and Tomoko for their tireless efforts and definitely will be returning to AMAN Tokyo whenever I'm in Tokyo again.Great team and Thank you from the bottom of my heart!Joe W

Wow! this is one of the best five hotels I have ever stayed in. The rooms are spectacular!Not to miss: the SPA (maybe the best urban SPA in the world) and the afternoon tea at the lobby. I also loved the Japanese breakfast.

I'll be honest I stayed at this hotel for the insta - the views, the interior design, the pool and onsen and personal bath. Did not disappoint at all. They nail the atmosphere and ambiance 10/10. I've read reviews that the service has been slightly subpar for a hotel of this price tag - can't really say much on that as we didn't interact with the staff much other than to book a shuttle back to the airport, which worked out without any issue. Check-in/checkout was also fine. I also read the food was not that great either - that at least I can attest to. the breakfast was fine since it came included when I booked through my card, but I sincerely don't want to know how much it actually cost because it was not worth a remark or even a photo on my insta story. The cocktails at the lounge were phenomenal. Didn't have any food, but enjoyed the live music. The pool and hot tub in the spa area were true highlights. I love the design of the hotel although I could see why someone would call it "dreary" as we were referring to it as the Edo Death Star. But I found the aesthetic extremely calming and very zen.

review_body: amazing hotel. great location!the only thing thats troublesome is having the change elevators to get to the room. amazing view. the rooms had great bath and room! high ceiling. good sound insulations. airconditioning was perfect. amazing food!

Ended up regretting the whole experience instead. We booked multiple suites for our family getaway months in advance. Looked forward to it with a great anticipation as we’ve been wanting to stay at Aman Tokyo for a while. Pretty much on night one, we knew it was going to be a letdown, and what a shame. The check in process was not perfect. The staff started talking with one person in our group and then in the middle moved over to talk to another person to give the rest of the information about our stay. Annoying.The concierge was pretty great before we checked in making a bunch of arrangements for our family. But they made some mistakes. They don’t even know when their own restraints are open and closed. They told us their sushi restaurant is closed and we had to book another place just to find out their restaurant is indeed open that day. Even the restaurant receptionist couldn’t believe it. You can tell they are inexperienced. The phone lines are always busy. Some nights no one picks up the phone. They promise to have someone call you back. Never happened. Extremely annoying. Should this happen at a place like Aman?The worst. The food. Room service and the breakfast are so extraordinarily mediocre, it’s actually mind boggling. With all the resources they have at their disposal, this is what they came up with? Even their Japanese food is not so great. How can this be?It says call Laundry for shoe shine in their guide. When I call, they ask “do you want to clean your own shoes?” Um...no. “Let me find out and call you back”. Really?!?!My young child was sick. Can you get us something to help the fever? The first thing they say to you every time is “this will cost you this much and that will cost you this much”. We missed the last hotel we stayed where one of us got sick and they brought in a whole kit and caboodle of medicine and amenities to help you get better without any concern for recovering cost. They actually cared for their guests’ health. How about that for a concept?! We are spending tens of thousands of dollars at this place and this is all you get? Sure the rooms and nice and the view is great. But little things go a long way when it comes to luxury hotels. Aman tragically falls short....even after some heart to heart talk with their manager on duty. Not much improvement. Stay at many other luxury hotels in Tokyo at half the price. Come for a drink in the lobby and leave.

Don’t get me wrong the hotel is VERY impressive. The lobby is really stunning, the spa is to die for , the service top notch , breakfast so so. Now the room is very nice , great to take a picture, but not as comfortable as you may think. If you spouse gets up to the bathroom the light wakes you up as well as the noise from the sliding doors and flush . This is in a regular room and in the suite which I stayed in both . If this hotel was a bit more expensive as peninsula , ritz , fourseasons etc ... it would be a great option . But this hotel is more than double those hotel prices and honestly is not worth it . Better stay at another a go have tea at the amazing lobby. Loved it just bad price quality ratio!

Upon entering the lobby lounge, there’s a very peaceful zen feeling. The staff are very attentive and professional. The room and public spaces are immaculate. The interiors are well designed and built with high quality and attention to detail. As a sign of the hotel’s thoughtful touches, we were delighted there was a Christmas tree in our suite for the holidays. I particularly liked the slate stone walls and tub in the bathroom. Rooms facing the Imperial Palace Gardens can also see Mt Fuji. There’s also a view of Tokyo Tower. The hotel is conveniently located.

This is the best hotel I have ever stayed at. the personnel almost float to serve you and make your stay a remarkable one . Quiet, full of fantastic features and great restaurants. The rooms are beautiful and they all have an amazing view of Tokyo. Is a combination of simplicity and comfort at the same time. beautiful light woods with deep grey granite floors and accents. exceptional bathrooms and Japanese soaking tubs on each room. Beautiful spa as well.The pool is also a magical spot fool of windows on a very high floor. they keep the temperature of the water and the space in perfect harmony so you don't feel cold while leaving the pool.The Italian restaurant Arva is a must ...yes. sometimes you have to try international food in Japan!Is a expensive hotel, but you are paying for an experience ...not a hotel.

We arrived at the hotel at about 7:30 in the morning, all hotel staff we met from the entrance to guestroom said hello to us with my name. I sent an email to the hotel to request an early morning check-in and we got it, which was very important for us to take a good sleep after a five hours night flight from Hong Kong, and then my wife and I could start our Tokyo exploring in the same day afternoon. Our guest room had a panoramic view of the royal residence and the garden, we were lucky to see the Fiji Mountain since it was sunny and the air was so clear. The black theme afternoon tea was amazing and a must try item. Dinner was tasty with reasonable price and the turn down service gift------the honey cake was so delicious. The design of the guestroom especially the bath tube and the daybed along the floor to ceiling window were unforgettably comfortable.

I spend 4 days in the Aman in Tokyo. As i know the Aman level a bit i was expecting high level. The realty was even better. Its hard to say in words but they did a fantanstic job. I have never been in a hotel where all areas are outstanding. Spa, rooms, design, service, food etc etc top of the top. Thank you a lot

It is a great hotel with big beautifully appointed rooms, stunning bathrooms and sleek interiors. Staff was super friendly. Sometimes communication in English was difficult. I loved the bar with the lethal views (and for recreational smokers the adjacent fumoir was a big plus!). While the food at the bar was pleasant, I went once to the Italian restaurant and I was seriously disappointed.

Can I move in?? Views, views, and more views from everywhere!! Stunning property, beautiful lobby, fantastic restaurant, delicious cocktails, modern, sleek, simple but brilliant! The Aman Tokyo feels like an Aman property in the middle of Tokyo! The rooms are similar to Amangiri in Utah but high up in a skyscraper with incredible views. The only problem with this property is that you never want to leave to sightsee. The views from the bed, couch lounge, and bathroom are incredible! We did a sunset swim in the indoor pool, worked out in the gym with views from every piece of equipment and ate dinner in the restaurant with views from every table. The only thing I can say that I would like to change is for drinking water to be served in glass bottles in the rooms. Providing plastic water bottles to guests is not environmental, modern or the style I feel that an Aman would want to represent. I am sure, however, that the Aman will change this for their properties in the near future; at least I hope so! We truly enjoyed our stay, and we hope to return!

Amazing dinner, chef Hiraki and chef Ghezzi created interesting dishes .Raw materials first level.Real italian flavour.beauty and style for each creations.Top Wine Ferrari spumante.I hope to come back soon

This hotel blew me away and quite frankly I am not a huge Tokyo fan. The room was beautifully appointed and quiet. The staff was beyond accommodating and the spa was sublime. The pool is probably the most special facility that one could ever experience at any establishment and the massages were heavenly. I would have been happy to skip the touring to spend my days within the four walls of the hotel.

review_body: I had the priviledge to spend 3 nights in Tokyo at the Aman. The room was well appointed in a very modern Japanese way. It was spacious and well thought of for overall a very comfortable stay. The view fron the 37th floor was beautiful overlooking the city as well as the imperial palace park. It was also well located within the city, near shops and restaurants as well as the main train station. I was able to walk undergound on a rainy day through very clean (and busy) pedestrian tunnels from the hotel to the train station. Some people may find the impressive 33rd floor lobby a bit " cold" though due to its size and dark black lava stone... It is a matter od taste...

Top of the class service, quality and experience. I couldn’t recommend this hotel more highly. They treat with the upmost respect and courtesy. I would highly recommend this to anyone traveling to Tokyo.

review_body: We spent 5 nights at Aman, and this was one of the highlights of our stay in Tokyo. Honestly, some days we just felt like hanging out at the hotel, which is not something you usually do in a city! The design is exquisite, the food is (mostly) delicious, although we do recommend to eat Japanese instead of Italian (the café, which serves French food, was also a big disappointment). The views are spectacular (even from the gym!) and the rooms are stunning. But the most important aspect is that the staff is seriously amazing. So polite, friendly, willing to help, always ready to provide advice, maps... you name it.

I can't praise Aman Tokyo enough. This review is a little late as I stayed for the first time in August 2017, but the quality has remained consistently excellent. I don't think there is a single item that I can fault about the property.Let's start with the rooms. I stayed in a Premier. The room is beautiful, bright and spacious: an example of clean Japanese design, with every comfort. The bed is slightly raised from the lounging area, thus affording beautiful views over the city. The bathroom features a very nice deep-soak bathtub and enjoys the same views over the city.The lobby, restaurant, bar and communal areas on the reception floor are stunning. Every corner enjoys gorgeous views. I particularly appreciated the cigar lounge (the Fumoir); it seems that Japan doesn't have a big smoking culture, so having a nice ambience to enjoy cigars is a rare treat for Tokyo. The whisky selection is outstanding and reasonably priced considering the level of the establishment. Service impeccable.The pool is another masterpiece of design. It offers incredible views (have a swim at sunrise or sunset!) and is a very serene environment. You can order drinks and nibbles there, which is a plus.What really stood out for me was the level of service from the Concierge team. In a city that might be somehow difficult to navigate for a foreigner, the Concierge at Aman made the real difference throughout my stay. They were able to book the hardest-to-get restaurants and, more importantly, recommend places that would have been impossible to find for a foreigner. Truly impeccable.Overall, an outstanding experience and certainly one of the very best city hotels in the world.

It comes at a hefty price but if you want to spoil yourself and someone you love stay here. Room was huge as at all Amans - and considering this is Tokyo made it feel all the more luxurious. Much nicer and more sophisticated IRL than it would seem based on the pictures on TA. View over the Imperial Palace especially during sunset was impressive. The gym was very impressive and you have it basically all to yourself and the pool an haven of serenity. Staff attentive, obliging and friendly.

食事にはたくさんの要素がある。食材、料理方法が先ずは基本。誰と食べるか、店の雰囲気も大切。アマン東京に行くとそこに加えてグローバルとか誰も知らない料理、と言った追加キーワードが加わる。ゼッカはアマンのルーツを日本に求めたと言う人もいる。世界中の辺境地、夢の国の料理人達を東京に連れてきては料理の再現をするアマン東京。そこには食材や料理方法だけでは決して買えない何かに対価を支払う価値がある。There are many criteria which decide how excellent the restaurant is. Materials and way of cooking are minimum requirement. Friends and atmosphere of the restaurant are also important. Mr. Adrian Zechariah built his resorts in the heart of dreams. If you go to Aman Tokyo, you will enjoy tastes in the land of frontier by local chef.

This hotel has the best views I have seen for a very long while.all the rooms have astonishing views of the city. the rooms are very spacious and the service is very good.the only thing that could be better is the breakfast

I stumbled into the lobby and my mouth dropped. I’ve been to a few Amans and other hotels that are ‘at one with nature’ but this was on another level. I was left in wonder. The rooms don’t let you down either with floor to ceiling breathtaking views of the city laid out in-front. Pool was amazing and the gym was acceptable-it had a concept 2 rower-and not just your go to sleep techno treadmill, elliptical etcIt’s popular with the people of Tokyo which is always a good sign, the bar fills out at night and the lobby is a hive of activity for afternoon tea. Superb service.

In Tokyo a concierge is key and the Aman's was superb. They got us into lots of challenging restaurants and were very responsive.The hotel is great. Rooms are very comfortable. I loved the bathroom.The bed was superb and view was out of this world.Service was excellent - management, door persons, etc. All superb.The lobby is a bit of a zoo. Different from a typical quiet Aman.Overall a great stay.

The usual Aman hospitality, amazing reception/lounge area and a comfortable bar and library. The concierge services weee excellent, dealing with a misunderstanding for an existing restaurant reservation and finding us somewhere equally good at short notice. The pool and spa are amazing, as is the gym

Superb hotel albeit pricey ..rooms are well designed Great service beautiful lobby but the music that was played in the afternoon was not up to par ..potential but just missed the mark restaurant breakfast was great dont miss it Great views nice spa but the massage was only so so which was surprising Concierge rocks ... really dedicated, personal service a real treat

review_body: This entire hotel is in a mellow trance of calmness... it’s quiet .It’s luxurious It’s beautiful Very beautiful hotel rooms. We had 2 upgraded rooms that felt like apartments ... bigger than many NYC apartments !!!But, very very expensive !!! Hard to find a more expensive hotel, but it was very nice and service impeccable .I did not love the Avra Italian restaurant on site, but the Breakfast is delicious .Gym has top quality technogym equipment ... and it could have the longest swimming pool in Tokyo... the entire length of the hotel

The rooms are amazing (lie in bed and watch the sun go down from your room with full height windows on the 33rd floor). The most memorable part for me was the swimming pool at night - a proper full length pool ‘in the sky’ that was a tranquil oasis which completely relaxed me after hot days in the Tokyo summer. Impossible to photograph at night so you’ll need to stay there to experience it!

We went to this hotel for a second time this summer, and it certainly did not disappoint!!For me it is one of the best urban hotels you can find. From the amazing decor to the outstanding service, this hotel lacks nothing.Our room was also just fantastic, it embodies Japan’s old tradition but in a very beautiful modern design. It was extremely spacious with an amazing view over the skyline of tokyo. To toilet was also just amazing! Would definitely recommend taking a traditional japanese bath in the hot-tub.Location was also great, walking distance to a lot of nice things, and the Tokyo train station of you are going further away.Overall the experience was amazing and the staff was charming!If I had to change one thing it would be the breakfast so I can put more choices on the menu or make it a buffet style which I prefer. Thank you very much for our great time there!ありがとう！

This is my first Aman experience and all I can say is...why can't all hotels be like that? I realize the price of the room is higher but not that much more than other hotels I've be in...but the level of service is disproportionately higher than most. As an employee, regardless of how much I am paid, one would think you would want to be on top of your game and do the best you can...but apparently other hotels didn't get that memo. But with the Aman Tokyo, they clearly did and whatever the company culture is or training they provide, it certainly works! They did not disappoint. This would be a great case study for hotel managers world wide.Property is as luxurious and perfect as expected. Luxury without being ostentatious, every details has been thoughtfully designed and executed. I appreciate the balance of both traditional and contemporary Japanese architecture throughout...from the common areas to the rooms to the spa to the gym...etc. Everything positive I have to say is reflected on the other reviews here and other publications. It is truly as magical as people say it is (despite being in the center of Tokyo FiDi). I was fortunate that they upgraded me to a suite (which was a real treat) but I understand even the regular rooms are sufficiently sized and has the same level of detail in design.As much travel as I do for work, and as many hotels as I stay (high end and low end), it all comes down to the staff and the service. It was perfect. It was understated, personable and flexible. Luxury does not mean over the top and overt display of brown nosing but rather considerate but personalized service that is not based on a check list. Staff are given a lot of trust and leeway to exercise discretion with management support. That is what works and why it works. From the 2 guys (from Ghana and Uganda) on arrival, to all the check in staff, supervisor Yuko, the concierge team, housekeeping team, room service, spa, etc...it was consistent throughout. They remember you by name and greet you regardless when they bump into you in the hallways. Really felt like "home" as that's important when traveling on long business trips. They are constantly ahead of you and anticipating what you might need. As you approach the elevator, they ask if you need a taxi so you don't have to wait. They coil up your charging cords in your room (I know small detail). They noticed I took a bath the night before, so during turn down the next night, housekeeping automatically lit the "candle" in the bathroom anticipating I would want to do the same that night. It's as if they kept thinking "how would I like to be treated or would expect if I was staying here?" while doing their work. I give a lot of credit to the staff because as much training as you can give, it only works if the staff put their heart into it. And they certainly did (despite being a job). Highly recommended! And would recommend to hotel managers worldwide to stay at Aman properties (incognito) to experience and learn from their staff.
