review_body: My partner and I returned to Aman Tokyo this February, 2.5 years after our first visit in 2015. This hotel holds a special place in our hearts. We got engaged during our last visit to Aman Tokyo. The staff helped with so many of the details - they were largely responsible for the magical proposal experience. This stay was equally sublime. We requested our previous room - 411 and were not disappointed. I was pleased that they secured this for us despite being fully booked. My partner was running the marathon and we checked in just after he finished. Upon our arrival, he was given a really sweet congratulatory message signed by the front of house staff. We also were given a very nice bottle of wine to celebrate our engagement anniversary. From exquisite in-room breakfasts at dawn to late-night swimming and soaks in our private onsen, we truly made the most of every single minute we had during our four-night stay. Everything about The Aman Tokyo is perfect. It’s peaceful but still thrilling. Mysterious yet feels like home. The service is modern Japanese perfection. Tokyo has become a place of pure joy for my partner and I. The Aman is a huge part of that joy for us. We will most definitely be returning as soon as the fates allow.

In Tokyo finding a big room would be a challenge. But when you deal with Aman, they always want to make you happy. It's the same case with this beautiful hotel. The room is minimalistic, modern and big. I had an amazing view overlooking the city! I quit enjoyed spending time in the library where I could be in private. The SPA is amazing! Seriously, the best spa you can dream of! I had one of the best dry Japanese massages in my life! The location is very convenient. You can get anywhere in Ginza writhing 15 min by car. Unfortunately, they charge a fortune for the car service. So, I highly recommend to use local taxi services instead of taking a hotel car.

I've been with a group of friends always staying in prime hotels, and we agreed unanimously that this was the most beautiful, most impressing, best hotel we'd ever been to. Very decent and tasteful luxury. Rooms! Views! Fuji-San! Lobby! Pool! Bar! Breakfast! All perfect! We loved it! Thank you!

Even by the minimalist standards of the AMAN brand, the hotel blew away our wildest expectations. We were greeted at the expansive lobby with a glass of chrysanthemum tea to enjoy the sweeping views of Tokyo (lobby is on the 33rd floor) while they checked us in and printed out all of our dining confirmations. Make sure to grab a cocktail as the sun sets along the towering glass windows before heading out to dinner. The colors that fill the space are spectacular. So it comes as a shock that you are even more WOWED by views from the glamorous, enormous suites. Ours was a corner suite on the 37th floor and arguably the nicest hotel room we've ever stayed in. The room is split into two sides with two bathrooms, one work space, dining room, kitchenette and living room area. The master that resides on the other side is same in size; however, it's peppered with the perfect amount of storage space, sitting areas, and the most 'wow' factored master bath, which includes a bathtub that kisses the side of the building and feels like an out-of-body infinity pool experience hovering over the city. You will feel the need to take a million photos of the space, as it is jaw dropping. What makes this an over the top experience is the combination of HUGE rooms with an elegant yet refined modern Japanese aesthetic. The Aman nails it! The service is unparalleled. They will do anything to make sure any need is met during your stay! There is a gorgeous indoor pool and spa on the 34th floor, so make time you schedule some downtime to enjoy it. Luxury all the way... this is a hotel to book if you want to treat yourself and indulge as a couple!

I spent four nights at the Aman Tokyo recently. It is, without a doubt, the most stunning city hotel I've had the pleasure to visit. The soaring lobby has to be seen to be believed; amazing, panoramic views from the restaurant and lounge, a beautiful spa, pool, and gym. The guest rooms are also stupendous with similar panoramic views over much of Tokyo. I felt like I was in my own private, luxurious cocoon, with all the expected five star amenities one could want. Sleep was deep and uninterrupted by noise, light, or temperature. Fantastic air-conditioning, the lack of which is deal-breaker for me.I ate an included breakfast daily - the same set menu items but quite generous including juice, fruit, yogurt, a choice of a couple of egg entrees, meat, and various breads. There is also a Japanese breakfast option which I did not try. I had two meals in the lounge and both were tasty and reasonably priced. Together these choices seemed a bit limited, but the property sits on top of the Otemashi station and there were a number of excellent small restaurants (as well as a gourmet market) on the lowest level to choose from.The service from Aman staff ranged from excellent to very good, with one snooty lounge employee. They were unfailingly polite, deferential, and helpful. The wait staff in the restaurant and lounge were young and seemed a bit inexperienced; they forgot a couple of requests and were not as attentive as one might like. What seemed to be lacking was an overall personal touch. For example, I expect five star properties to reach out to me before the stay to inquire about transportation, spa, or restaurant reservations. I heard nothing from the Aman, although I did email them and there was a prompt response. I was not greeted by name and only the concierge seemed to remember me. No one asked if I was enjoying my stay or if there was anything I needed. It is unclear to me if the seeming lack of warmth is cultural, Aman-based, a combination of the two. Or maybe my expectations were unreasonable. One final comment about relative price. The hard product was worth every penny/yen spent. But would I return? Probably not, when there are so many other luxury options in Tokyo that provide more all-around value for comfort, service, and luxury.

Our family of four world travelers, including a teenage girl (yikes) and an 11 year old boy (yikes again), as he needs to be entertained in every minutes otherwise “so boring”. Aman Tokyo so unanimously delivered for all of us, compelled to share with other families. Having the great privilege of staying at impossibly sublime properties on our journeys, it’s hard to make our jaws drop. We have seen the world through a privileged lens for which we are grateful everyday. Enter Aman Tokyo - jaw dropped X 4. Even the 11 year old. Sublime in every way! The corner suite with floor to ceiling windows was the first. The suite made had us comfortable and delighted. The service from every staff, the food, the spa, the little touches that Aman delivers with precision. Our children are now officially Aman junkies. I have been for 20 years, since first visiting Amanpuri. Amanjena in Morocco still captures my memory. Aman Turks and Caicos... to Aman Tokyo. We are off to China. Four “junkies” with full hearts and eager minds on our journey to see if four Aman properties in China may have our jaws to drop again and again.

The architecture of the hotel is incredible: the lobby attrium is dramatic, the spa has terrific views over Tokyo and even the guest room corridors are eye catching in their minimalistic design, lit from the floor. But the staff are the stars, a very Aman interpretation of high end Japanese service. Names are remembered, as are details from previous Aman stays. A great stay.

We’ve stayed at various hotels around the world with our family of six. We found the staff at Aman to be a bit stuffy, lacking a friendly charm. Seems like they cater to adults and couples rather than a family with children. Early check in (Amex)was not met as we were able to get into our rooms by 1:30p. Hallways were hot as were the elevators. One option for dining. Limited menu. Do not recommend this hotel if you have young children.

Aman Tokyo is one of those hotels that define luxury and sublimity. It is located in the very heart of Japan - Otemachi in the Chiyoda District of Tokyo, the political and financial heartland of Japan. Japan's national parliament, financial district and the Imperial Palace are all within walking distances, making you feel like being part of the upper class.The decorations are superb - modern luxury to the extreme, with an inconceivably spacious lobby on the 33rd floor and guest rooms above. And the view from your bed is another reason why you shouldn't miss this hotel. I had stayed at many top hotels in the world, but few of them offered a view with such magnificence. From the giant French window, you can see the entirety of the Imperial Palace complex, including the palaces with green roofs. Beyond those is the cluster of skyscarpers in the prosperous Shinjuku District, which are quite a sight, especially at night. Also, you can watch the sunrise and sunset right from your bed - a gigantic sun hangs right in the sky.Among the various top hotels I've stayed at, I rank Aman Tokyo among the top three. It is an ideal choice for budget-incensitive guests.

My wife and I visited the Aman Tokyo on our recent trip to Japan. We stayed at the Aman on May 8-11 and again on May 17-19. It was wonderful. Where to begin?The hotel is physically gorgeous. A sweeping lobby and dining area contain breathtaking views of Tokyo and beyond. On one clear morning, we were able to see Mt. Fuji. The hallways reminded us of a bamboo forest, lovely and fragrant. The rooms were a blend between East and West, with sliding doors and high tech amenities. The service? It was unparalleled. By the time we left, I think 8 different employees knew our names. The front desk staff, the concierge, and the bellmen could not have been nicer or more professional. No request was too much. At the restaurants on site (all marvelous), everyone was warm and welcoming. The food was interesting and outstanding. The spa and fitness facilities were first rate. We did not want to leave. This is the finest city hotel we have ever visited.

Beautiful hotel specially architecturally. Great bathroom with a very nice tub. Beautiful swimming pool. Great dinner. Great location. Our young children enjoyed the pool greatly.We were most impressed by the service after we left the hotel. We lost our iPhone on the Shinkansen just before flying out of Japan. The hotel sent staff to the station to pick it up from lost and found, and posted to us internationally! No other hotel would be this helpful.

This Aman is set on the top 8 floors of a building. I got a standard room which i found beautiful and very spacious. Make sure you ask for a room facing the imperial palace as the other side does not have very nice views at all. The food, service, facilities live up to the Aman name. Simplicity and elegance are what comes to mind in every corner. It is a stones throw away from Marunouchi Street with great shopping.

Location:It's close to Tokyo Station making it easy to catch the train to and from the airport. However, it is located in the business district so it is not interesting as far a restaurants or other services for travelers. If you like jogging, it is close by the Imperial Palace, a great place for jogging. Common areas:The lobby is huge and beautifully decorated. It's very spacious for Tokyo. The pool and gym are world class. Room:One of the largest rooms I have stayed in. And the view of the Imperial Palace is pretty amazing too. I love the simple minimal esthetic. The bathroom is spacious and definitely love the heated floor. It's super in everyway. Service:There is room for improvement. Like most of high end hotels, front desk leads you to a seat while they take care of the check-in and registration. Unlike other high end hotels that I have been to in that no drinks were offered while waiting. A simple glass of water would suffice. Some sort of cold juice even better. There were too many non-guests using the restaurants so there is no seat for lunch other than the bars. That is a real disappointment. There should be some seats allotted for guests. Shouldn't that be one of the perks of staying there? Service at the pool was very nice. Pool people promptly bring out water, menu, and goggles. Food was more than adequate. Love the fries that came with the sliders. Cocktails could be better. They lack that oomph. But I am picky. Of the many cocktails I have tried (from the Ritz in Paris to Sukhothai in Bangkok), very few standout such as the mojito and margarita at the Ritz in Laguna Beach. Had a few rounds but none amazing or memorable. Being a picky person that I am, this hotel definitely worth staying when in Tokyo.

We recently visit Tokyo and stayed at the Aman and Hoshinoya Tokyo.We try to stay at the different Aman hotels in the world and we had to experience Aman Tokyo.Aman Tokyo is a spectacular hotel, however didn't feel it was at the level at other Aman hotels we have stayed. I would have given a 4.5 stars if was possible.The location of the hotel is great and the lobby is spectacular, the views of the city are unparalleled.We usually book through Fine Hotels and Resorts and most of the times we get upgraded.The hotel was full and there were no upgrades available, however at check in, they mentioned that because my room was the highest level before a Suite, I would not have been able to been upgraded as upgrades are within same room category.This might be true for certain hotels, but when you stay at an Aman hotel and pay close to $2000/night, usually you are upgraded even if you are in a different category room like a suite. This is what differentiates a true luxury hotel, regardless of their official policy.I imagine the upgrade would have been done to a Suite if rooms were available, but I thought that was something had never heard in any Aman.The room was spacious, nicely decorated and beautiful with spectacular views over the city.We were a little disappointed about the welcome gifts as they were a few strawberries and crackers. No chocolate or anything for turn down service.We did have the traditional Japanese breakfast, which I did like and was very nicely presented.The pool is spectacular overlooking the city.After staying at the Hoshinoya and the Aman, I did enjoy more the stay at Hoshinoya, however the views, architecture and rooms are spectacular at the Aman. Nice hotel, maybe not the best value compared to other luxury hotels in Tokyo, but worth experiencing.

Big Claim, I KNOW..... It is, though. A hotel that much like the cuisine that shines because of simplicity and not unnecessary addition. Clean lines, high ceilings, nods everywhere to Shintoism and nature, the hotel is breathtaking in it's clean lines, space and quiet. The hotel sits on the top floors of the Otemachi Tower close to the East Gate of The Imperial Palace. The Aman is perfectly situated in the financial district of Tokyo, close to subways and an easy walk to the Imperial Palace. You can easily explore Tokyo without needing a taxi. The lobby of the hotel is an open, high-cielinged homage to modern and sleek design. With no clutter or unneeded accessories, the giant plume of cherry blossoms erupting from the reflecting pool in the middle of the lobby was captivating. Do yourself a favor and have a final evening drink after your night out, the music, the lighting, and the mood of the place will transport you to another state of mind. The hallways to the rooms are beautifully lit, wide and totally unpopulated. Sconces containing sprigs of greenery dot the hallway which you will be tempted to take in but once the door to your room enters will you will be drawn to floor to the ceiling windows laying Tokyo and its maze of possibility before you.Your hotel room is beautifully decorated with simple decorations and nothing that pulls you from the amazing view. The shower and tub also have the same amazing view of the city (I am hoping the glass was not see through because I could not bear to close the blinds as the city is the ultimate night light).Finally, what catapults this hotel into the GREATEST category are the individuals that work there. Without exception, they are lovely. Truly, lovely. They really do care. It's not hospitality, they are kind and helpful and gracious (as were all the locals I met). Please look up Mikki at the front desk who is exceptional. A beautiful person inside and out, I will never forget her kindness and help.Make good use of the concierge- as with all Aman's they have the excursion program down! Tokyo, however, is easy and fun to navigate. I can't wait to go back (and I will be back).

One of my favourite of the Aman hotels and one of favourite hotels in the world! Exactly what you’d expect from an Aman - superb rooms, excellent service, incredible food and the best gym and pool in any hotel in Japan I am aware of... all wrapped up in the usual Aman peace, serenity and calm.

My family spent two nights here in a Suite class room. Even as the "smallest" room, it was so spacious as to echo! I definitely don't think a larger room was necessary for our family. The room itself consisted of a loft type area, featuring a King bed (and requested, fluffy cot for our son), TV stand separator and a step down, followed by a sitting/eating area against window seats and floor-to-ceiling windows. The bathroom features sliding doors and gorgeous decor. The separate toilet room was a nice feature, as someone could be getting ready at the double sinks or bathing at the shower or tub and not worry about a privacy issue. The floors were always warm. What impressed me the most about the suite was the large soaking tub (ofuro). It came with fresh salts and herbs, and overlooked the Imperial Palace. Wow, what a view! The Aman takes up the top few floors of this Otomachi building, so you go through other areas to get upstairs. But the entire time you are attended to like royalty. We used concierage several times both prior to and during the trip and found them to be extremely helpful and patient. Our package included breakfast for three, which was very nice as the expansive spread would have been out of our budget otherwise. My husband felt so pampered by the breakfast; additionally, when we arrived we receive "immune boosting shots" of some sort of juice. Hubby was VERY sick, so he definitely appreciated this. The management sent him bonus fruit and get well wishes too. We had one hitch in the trip, but it was resolved with care by management. Our son's cot was changed one morning and housekeeping hadn't noticed his stuffed animals rolled up into the bedding. When we returned in the evening, he was very upset to find them missing. Housekeeping and management took time late at night to find his stuffed animals, and also sent us gifts the next day as well in apology for the trouble. I can't say enough about the experience of staying here. It is an event in itself. The building is a work of art. The pool/spa floor has amazing views of everything you'd possibly want to see in Tokyo. And the experience of swimming ABOVE the city was something. Hubby and I got very bad sunburns climbing Mt. Fuji the day prior, so we appreciated all the pampering the spa had to offer. The ladies spa featured an enormous soaking tub overlooking the city, and huge, private showers. The locker room had individual vanities with spa lotions and necessities. I'm not sure what the lotions were, but they were the only thing I tried in Tokyo that soothed my painfully sunburned face. Additionally, I am big on cleanliness and this place was spotless. It even smelled different than any other hotel I have visited: some sort of sweet citrus that I couldn't get enough of.If our budget ever allows, we will definitely be back!

An amazing place with fantastic views of central Tokyo. When you walk out of the lift into the main reception area you are hit by the wow factor. Wonderful food and drink and general ambiance. A must if only to take in the interior and exterior.

This was my first visit to an AMAN hotel and I had incredibly high expectations after hearing so many great things about the AMAN hotel group.Arrival at the hotel was an experience. I adore minimalist design and the lobby of this hotel just blew my mind. I’ve never seen a more gorgeous space in my life - worth visiting if only for the lobby. I arrived early in the morning and the room was ready by 9am and I’d been upgraded to a premier room. Rooms are huge, perfectly designed and maintained. Note the whole hotel is very crisp, clean and somewhat simple in design so may not suit everyone’s tastes. However the quality of the design is of the highest standard. Views are stunning - even on a bad day. I loved everything in the room from the bathtub at the window, the lounge area and the out of this world bed. Best bed ever. Tokyo struggles to compete with your room I promise you.The one area I’ve heard AMAN hotels excel in is service. Whilst they certainly exceeded in quality of the hotel I did not find the service to be exceptionally good - I did not find it as good as the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo for example. Everyone was friendly and the early check in was much appreciated but nothing memorable happened to make the service stand out - I wasn’t greeted by name, given a complimentary drink on check-in or asked how my stay was going. First world problems but if I compare this to say Claridges, London, they should do better.On to the amenities. The pool WOW. That’s all. WOW. I had a hot stone massage which was perfection and the gym was great too. The breakfast was fab! The American breakfast is vast and high quality. Aside from that my dining experiences at the hotel were quite poor. I had lunch in the lounge but the host would not offer me a window seat despite there being several available. Twice I went to the bar and had champagne and twice the glass was only half-filled (this truly annoyed me) and dinner at Arva was well below standard.Realize i’m moaning a lot here but this is the most expensive hotel in Tokyo and AMAN has an incredible reputation so my expectations were high.I would still highly recommend this hotel and gladly come back. It is so visually stunning I couldn’t risk staying anywhere else in Tokyo.

Aman TokyoOne of the most beautiful urban hotels I have experienced. I did not know what to expect and wondered how Aman could be translated in a bustling city. Aman is a special destination within unfettered landscapes. Aman Tokyo seems to transcend conventional luxury city hotels. Taking the top floors of a high rise office building allows for spectacular views. The design is effortless and calming incorporating natural elements of stone wood and metal. The natural design is seamlessly found throughout the whole hotel. You enter on the street level and whisked up in an express elevator to the 40 something floor. You are greeted by gracious staff members and enter a soaring common space that blows you away. The floor to ceiling glass walls offer spectacular views of tokyo. The bar, lounge and restaurants fill the perimeter, while a sunken in common living room offers comfortable lounge seating with beautiful zen rock installation. The center of the room features a beautiful water feature with a seasonal grand arrangement. Rooms are simple, spacious and beautifully designed that allows the million dollar views of Tokyo. The best feature in the suite is the Onsen style bath. Come on! The views, the views, the views!Service exemplifies the Aman philosophy. I changed hotels when my mother arrived (she like the Peninsula Hotels) and it was night and day in the feel and service. One cannot explain, but rather have to experience. Spa was one of the most beautiful experiences I have ever had in my life. I love to spa wherever I go in the world and this one is bar none the best. I selected a “journey” experience that was truly heavenly. The facilities are insanely beautiful and well appointed. Food was great at breakfast, dinner was a bit disappointing. Service was amazing. The bar and lounge is a wonderful experience at night. It is a very Sexy ambiance. I was blown away in how much I enjoyed this first “urban” Aman, I can’t wait to see what NYC does.

A city ‘aman’ tends to be more business like than other Aman properties where the GM comes out to greet you in person. It is still an oasis in Toyko centre with stunning views. Lying next to the indoor pool soaking in the sights of the city lights in the evening is definition of luxury. Beautiful room, pleasant service and recommendable stay!

There are many fine hotels in Tokyo, but the relatively new Aman Tokyo is without a doubt the best in terms of rooms/suites (all huge!), spa, facilities and service. The food is excellent if you want western cuisine, and my only wish would be to also offer a Japanese menu at lunch and dinner. Having said that, rich Japanese flock to Aman and it seems to be THE place for immaculately dressed Japanese ladies to have tea with their friends.

review_body: The best hotel I have ever visited. Service is outstanding. Rooms are extraordinary with awesome views of Tokyo and impeccable technology. The swimming pool is spectacular. Hotel staff makes you feel like a king.

I've stayed at Grand Hyatt, Ritz, Mandarin, and visited countless others (peninsula, imperial, palace etc) and used to exclusively stay at the Mandarin but when their GM left and having experienced Aman at Amangiri, I decided it was time to switch it up and try the aman in Tokyo.Turned out to be a very good decision indeed. From the start, the concierge, particularly, Yuriko, were super helpful in landing some difficult restaurant reservations: including the highlight of my trip, a personally prepared meal by a famous yakiniku chef at his restaurant counter. The facilities are stunning. The lobby is an architectural wonder. The rooms are by far the biggest and sleekest of Tokyo. Beautiful views, amazing dual vanity bathroom with rain shower and relaxing japanese bath (I used it daily!). Bed and layout were classic Aman. Housekeeping was consistent and discrete, and rarely bumped into them or were bothered in the morning.Finally, definitely take advantage of the pool in the spa area. I would exercise, work up a good sweat and then dip in the pool, come out and relax on the day-bed where a cold towel and fresh berries awaited. Simply zen!Breakfast was a-la-carte, which i personally prefer, but if you prefer buffets as is the standard in tokyo then you might be dissapointed. Buffets are not very hygienic and not as fresh, so I don't know why you would care, and i'm glad the Aman style of everything personalized and made-to-order was carried over here.

review_body: Great hotel. Kerry hill has designed a majestic ode to Zen minimalism with the usual Aman touches of natural materials and neutral hues. It's a beautiful space which maximises its panoramic views of Tokyo. We saw mount Fuji everyday we were there because of the clear weather. Move over Hyatt pool! There's a new indoor heated hotel pool king. Expansive views of Tokyo and the surrounding mountains. If they film lost in translation 2 they need to make it here!Aman Tokyo is Conveniently located at Otemachi - close to Tokyo station. You're within walking distance of JR trains and the Narita express at Tokyo station as well as metro lines at Tokyo and Otemachi stations. Service was fantastic. They helped pick up our luggage at Tokyo station, arranged hard to book restaurants and spared no effort to make us feel comfortable. Japanese service can sometimes come across as incredibly formal. But Aman Tokyo staff were really warm and friendly while maintaining etiquette! Really appreciated the restaurant staff, pool staff and manager Yoshi for taking care of us.

This is a very beautiful hotel - modern and minimalist. Having stayed at the mandarin in tokyo and at the ritz in kyoto - there is something left to be said about the service at the aman, it is not up to par with the two Hotels I previously mentioned. We had such an amazing stay at the other hotels that we were used to great service and when we got to this hotel we were bummed by the following:Check in took 20 minutesMy husband called in for breakfast for following morning and they said that the time he wanted was completely booked. For the price of the nightly stay this is not an excuse. When I ordered lunch, Room service did not answer the phone. The operator had to find someone at that dept to call me back when available. These things should not happen in any hotel, much less in this category. It has amazing views, amazing rooms, but it does not have the management training of a mandarin oriental or a ritz carlton.

This hotel is truly an exquisite experience. From the minute you walk in, you appreciate the zen feelings it evokes. The design is sophisticated and minimalist. The service is exceptional. Our room had breathtaking panoramic views. It was beautifully appointed and immaculate. A shoji screen opens up into the bathroom which has the traditional Japanese tub and separate rain shower. The products are all very high quality. Everyday different types of treats are delivered to our room. I believe that Aman sets a standard for excellence that few hotels can match.

Amazing service, amazing views, amazing bath, amazing dinner. We were lucky to have a room on the top floor thanks to Amex card services.Stayed here for 2018 New Year, and everything was perfect from dinner, to the common bathing area, to the room. Complimentary drinks that were refilled at turndown service. Breakfast was a little fiddly- I prefer a buffet so we can control the pace and not wait for the staff to bring everything to the table. But even so, this stay was 10 out of 10.

My friend and her husband are Aman VIP as they have stayed in numerous Aman around the world.We went to Toyko with them and they have followed us to stay in Conrad Toyko where we usually stayed when we went to Toyko. But upon the recommendation of our friend, we have made a fulfilling trip to Aman for lunch. We were greeted once we arrived at the reception and they have kindly taken us for a tour of the hotel before our lunch. The room was very spacious and every where in the hotel , you will have an impressive view of the city. The design of the hotel is very simple but yet ultra nice and classy. Everything is just right, not too much, not to little. The indoor heated pool with glass ceiling makes one have an immediate urge for a dip given the cold weather outside .One more thing worth mentioning is when our friend made the booking for lunch, he did not mention that it would be his birthday the day before. We were pleasantly surprised to find that they have prepared a yummy chocolate birthday cake for him.

Just stayed in the Aman Tokyo and, to be honest, I LOVED it !! I loved everything and I was very curious to see what were the reasons of the only handful of negative comments here.Had a look to them and what they mainly mention are problems with upgrades and early arrival... :-))Nothing important !And, for sure, I'd love to stay in the Aman for my next stay in Tokyo...

The exterior maybe an ordinary office block in the financial district, but as soon as you step out of the elevator into the main zen-like atrium of the hotel, you will be blown away. It is an amazing space. It also is vibrant with trendy people hanging out having tea, drinks or milling around. Then on the way to room, the corridors are magical. I had a room which had 3 huge floor-to-ceiling windows with panoramic views overlooking the Imperial Palace and way beyond. This includes the bathroom where I could sit in the bathtub and watch the sunset. I spent so much time just sitting by the window and looking at the view at sunrise, during the day, at sunset and at nighttime. The room was spacious, luxurious and modern, designed in a Japanese zen-like minimalist style. Breakfast was a-la-carte and was the most picture perfect. I had drinks at the bar which is a great place to hang out, great cocktails and snacks and gorgeous views. If you love design, try and stay here.

My second visit to Tokyo and to the Aman hotel there in the year - the hotel is blisteringly beautiful. It is squeaky clean, the staff are marvellous, the service throughout is exceptional, views, location, rooms, food - a complete treat.

The Christmas afternoon tea comes with unlimited use of drinks. Each bite was yummy with hints of surprise! Sting at the bar to enjoy beautiful Mount Fuji and sun set is highly recommended. There was beautiful lady wearing Kimono playing koto at the lounge. It was an delightful afternoon!

You don't need me to tell you that this is one of the world's very best hotels - nearly every detail is perfect and it's worth the splurge. The visual setting and design makes this hotel singular but the warm helpful staff sets it apart from others in the category. The Concierge staff (especially Yuriko) are the best I've ever encountered and go the extra mile months in advance of your arrival and up to the moment you are heading out to eat and have discovered one of your guests is going to be 30 minutes late (a call was made to the chef that made everything all right!). There should be a higher level than five stars for this one!

Oh, Aman Tokyo. My partner and I have returned to the property five times this year alone, and every time we go back I'm reminded of how truly exceptional their hard product is. If I could replicate one of their palace-view rooms in my own home, I would. As other reviewers have noted, the Aman Tokyo doesn't always meet the Aman standard for superlative hospitality, but they are improving. Breakfast service, which we'd found to be slow and disorganized on prior visits, was efficient, friendly, and on point this time. For instance, there was an American guest one table over from us who put in a very complicated breakfast order (he also nattered on his phone the whole time, but that's a whole other story), and the staff handled it with grace and accuracy. Also special kudos to Kei, who remembered my breakfast order *from five months ago* when we went downstairs the first morning. He's lovely and professional, exactly what an Aman employee should be. Likewise, the uneven concierge services seem to be improving. We had numerous requests on this trip (dinners, concert tickets, various appointments, etc.) and they handled all of them with aplomb. One critique: when we first checked in, we requested a late check-out on our departure day because we had a nighttime flight at Narita. The front desk staff approved our request, and we went upstairs happy. Five minutes later, the front desk phoned our room to say no, actually, they'd extended the late checkout offer to us in error and we would have to pay a half-day rate (which is over $500) to stay late. I called them back and said I was extremely disappointed that they could not extend the courtesy of a late checkout to us, especially since 1) they'd promised it to us already and 2) we visit the resort 5+ times a year (our first stay of 2018 is already booked, mind you). The on-duty manager (Ken, I believe) eventually granted us a complimentary late check out but he was quite rude about it, and the entire exchange left us feeling annoyed. If you mistakenly offer a benefit to a guest, don't renege on it and attempt to make the guest feel bad, especially if they are returning clients! Again, it was one of those unfortunate instances at the Aman where blind adherence to rules trumped basic principles of hospitality. So the Aman still has some considerable work to do here. We noticed that they have a new GM (seems the hotel has been through a few since it opened), and we wish her much luck in the role. We'd still rather stay at the Aman than anywhere else in Tokyo, but a hotel like this should always be striving continuously for improvement.

review_body: I always wondered how Aman Tokyo could ever replicate the feeling of other Aman's while being in the midst of such a hectic city. Well it does.From the moment you enter the amazing lobby , to the view of the rooms to the serenity of the pool. All is Aman. All is peace.The bar is great. The italian restaurant is great. The service is flawless.The prices are unbearable, but that's also part of Aman, so take it or leave it.

I visited Amon Tokyo in July, 2017. I used their lounge for afternoon tea. It's a great lobby lounge and food/dessert/tea was great. The serving size is large, so please bring a good appetite. Like any other restaurants in Japan, you cannot take any left over with you, even just a chocolate.

We thoroughly enjoyed our stay at the Aman Tokyo. The service is fantastic and extends from the porter at the front door to the concierge and everyone in between. The hotel has a beautiful lobby with ample seating to relax with tea or have a drink at the bar. Our room was equally as impressive and had floor to ceiling windows in the room and bathroom. The room was spotless, tranquil and well maintained. The bedding was excellent and it was possible to lay in bed and look out over Tokyo. Although it is a city hotel, it still has that Aman feel that we enjoy so much.

Excellent service as in all Aman chain. Great Good the design and architecture of the lobby and the rooms is breathtaking. The spa has great service but they use regular towels instead of soft cotton sheets, that I personally prefer. The restaurant has espectacular views and very good food. I would highly recommend this hotel for business or pleasure.

Located in the heart of Tokyo, this is an awesome property. Asthetically, its beautiful and tranquil. Clean and modern and spare its elegant in its own unique away. from the beginning off your stay at check in through the service in the hotel and spa it is literally perfect. Rooms are quite large by Tokyo standards and have plenty of space to relax and enjoy the view. Baths are spectacular and include a beautiful spa like atmosphere with lovely views from the shower over the city. Expensive but worth it.

review_body: I had very high expectations based on the other Amans I had stayed at. This hotel was definitely nice in many respects, but I didn't find it over-the-top spectacular like other Aman hotels. Perhaps the comparison of this city Aman to resort Amans is unfair. But if it's going to be branded as an Aman, then it should math the quality of other Amans

The Christmas special afternoon tea at this posh hotel was a great experience. The overwhelming gray of the property was fine for a lobby and I enjoyed its minimalistic feel. Also amazing was the live traditional Japanese music by a lady in kimono. A very delicate and exotic touch that I appreciated. The afternoon tea was amazing, the chocolate sled was a piece of art, the service was polite and courteous. Recommended.

I have stayed at my fair share of hotels around the world but the Aman in Tokyo is beyond outstanding; it’s one of those special properties you’ll remember for the rest of your life!Pros:-The design is high-end Japanese zen. Never seen anything like it.- The attention to detail is out of this world but still maintains a high level of Japanese simplicity.- Our room was just magical. The view was breathtaking; I could have sat in the room all day just admiring Tokyo from the expansive window.- Everyday we would find a very inconspicuous box on the side table that contained Japanese delights to eat!- The foyer is a masterpiece. Cons:- None!!

Minimalist design. Luxe details. The usual faultless Aman service. I have only stayed in one other Tokyo Hotel (Peninsula, quite good) but have visited many luxury hotels all over world. Aman Tokyo is right up there for a modern city hotel. Except for cost, I can't imagine a reason to stay anywhere else in Tokyo. Truely exceptional.

Location:The Aman is perfectly located. Walk a couple of blocks to the west and you're at the Imperial Palace. Walk a couple of blocks to the southeast and you're at the Tokyo Station. Hotel:The Aman is incredible. The style is very much minimalistic with Japanese flair. Our room faced the Palace, which I recommend! This hotel is well taken care of and feels new.Staff:Exceptional to say the least! From the moment that we arrived, the staff was incredibly attentive and helpful. The attention to details was was unparalleled. I would absolutely, without a doubt, stay at this hotel time and time again.

I'll try not to be overly gushing but this hotel in design and service is the best I ever experienced. It's soaring lobby, minimalist design and professional service combined for an exceptional experience. The room offered a view of the Tokyo skyline but if you didn't want the view a black automated curtain came down with the flick of a switch -- very uncomplicated compared to other systems I've dealt with. The bathroom had a traditional Japanese tub right next to the window so you can bathe with a view of Tokyo. It had every toiletry product you ever want or need. Of course it had the requisite automated toilet seat that worked perfectly. In fact everything worked perfectly throughout the hotel. Everything had a place in the room. It was discreet, luxurious, modern and comfortable.The spa and exercise facilities were top notch. Had my experience with a traditional Japanese bath. Used the gym, again with astounding views of the city. Did not have time to use the pool but boy did I want to. Plenty of very good western and Japanese choices for breakfast in the lobby restaurant. Service may have been too fawning at times, people opening the door for you leaving and entering the building is a bit much, but I experience this at other places as well like the Shanghai Peninsula, but that's an extremely minor complaint. Overall, it's an experience I would love to repeat.

The hotel has an impeccably minimalistic design and is in a great location, very close to the Tokyo metro station. The staff is wonderful. Friendly and professional. Breakfast is a la carte and tasty. Veri nice gym and pool.

High atop a building is the Aman Tokyo with its soaring lobby and graceful atmosphere. Booked an eighth-floor corner suite overlooking the Imperial Palace and grounds. The service was excellent and the hospitality and attention to its guests really shone here.The suite was in blond wood with tatami mates, floor-to-ceiling windows, a dining table, a large slate covered island, a wine cooler, and all one could want for serenity. Tastefull wooden Shoji lamps and minimal decoration enhanced the feelings of restful grace (really!).The shower ROOM (yes) with dark slate walls and floors also contained the slate soaking tub with a view over Tokyo. Oils and herbal net bags right at the tub.I have never been in such a luxurious, yet somehow elegantly simple suite. And I am familiar with supposedly similar venues in Sydney, Paris, London, Dubai, Singapore, and Milan--none compared with my tastes as did the Aman.This an experience that is well worth the rate. Plus, Tokyo was very interesting with superior tube/underground system.

What an amazing hotel. Minimalist beauty both inside and out. Only the Japanese can get so many details both with the hardware and software right. We enjoyed perhaps the best massage ever, anywhere at the spa. The staff was so well trained and so wonderfully talented. The lobby is achingly beautiful you could just sit and look at it all day. Our room (318) had a view that went for miles, was impeccably clean and everything worked. Topping off all the aesthetic beauty is the genuine caring nature of the staff. The concierge was fantastically helpful as we peppered them with multiple itinerary questions spread out all over the city. Prior to our arrival they had been proactive and assisted us in getting several dinner and lunch reservations. Upon our arrival, a written itinerary awaited us. We were enjoying an anniversary stay, and on our first night, there was a handwritten card, with messages from multiple staff members all over it - not only was it nice but that must have been time consuming. We will return and it is a hotel visit we will not soon forget.

Lovely setting for afternoon tea, have had many high tea's at various hotels around the globe, this one was quite special. Their 3 tier stand was black bamboo, very oriental, very eye catching. Service was impeccable and was the quality of the food served. Lovely scones, pastries and exquisite dainty chocolate shoes.A truly enjoyable way to spend the afternoon.

This is our first time staying at the Aman. The hotel occupies the top 6 levels of the Otemachi Tower located in Tokyo's financial district close to the Imperial Palace and Tokyo Station. We arrived in Tokyo by train and since the hotel is a close proximity to Tokyo Station, we decided to walk to the hotel instead of taking a taxi. What we thought could be a tedious walk turns out to be an easy 8 minutes stroll in the cooling weather on a wide walkway without much people along the way.The moment we entered the Aman, we were greeted by extremely warm and friendly staff where they immediately assisted with our luggage and escorted us to the lobby on the 33rd floor. The details that the staff exhibited are what were lacking in a lot of high end hotels that we have stayed before. The front desk receptionist who attended to our check-in was polite and gracious. She gave an introduction of the hotel and even escorted us to our room where she further explained every little details of the room that we should be made known of and answering every of our questions with knowledge. We had a premier room beautifully designed in traditional Japanese style fitted with modern technologies that comes with a magnificent view of the city skyline with the sight of the Tokyo SkyTree. As it was my partner's birthday, they have specially prepared a surprise that consisted a plate of assorted pastries, a bottle of wine and a well wishes card fully hand written and signed by a couple of staff from the reservation office, front desk and concierge. It was an exceptional surprise for the generous arrangement.On the day we are leaving, we requested the front desk to arrange a taxi for us to Tokyo Station for our Narita Express to the airport. Instead a complimentary hotel limo was arranged to give us a lift to the station. This had really caught us by surprise.And lastly, what was truly heart warming was that the chauffeur see us off standing in the drizzle until we had entered the station safely. These little gestures throughout the stay had really touches the heart of the guests making a lasting impression. We will surely be back again when the chance arise.

I lived in Tokyo and I still visit a couple of times a year so I was really excited about staying at the Aman since I had wonderful experiences. I'd often say that the usual Aman service is like ninjas. They appear out of nowhere and clean up after us and disappear. But not the Tokyo Aman. We had a couple of rooms because we took a family trip but little details like missing snacks and drinks were noticeable from the minibar area. It may seem like minuscule details but when you are paying $1000 plus per night per room the little services matter. And the room was nice and spacious but it seemed really empty. And the bar closes really early (before 12pm). And there isn't much dining options. The breakfast is really photogenic but nothing special. So for the price the location and everything else I don't recommend it. Well the concierge was really helpful but for a better price, room and all round service I recommend Ritz Carlton instead.

review_body: To my opinion, after staying in few Amans, one and only and many four seasons hotels - I think the Aman hotel in Tokyo is the best hotel in the world. It is just ridiculously amazing. Don't miss: the SPA, The afternoon tea and the Japanese bath in the rooms.

The hotel was simply beautiful. Despite being located in a building, the rooms were filled with light! The rooms were spacious and comfortable with Japanese decor. The staff were friendly.There were smoking options available but the hotel was still mostly smoke free.

...I relaxed. We checked into Aman after a 4 night stellar stay at the Peninsula Tokyo, where we were upgraded from a room to a mid-tier suite and treated to to/from transportation in the hotel's Rolls - a lot to live up to, right?We were greeted on the ground floor and escorted up to the 33rd floor for check-in. We arrived at roughly 2:15 pm, so our room was not ready - although we were on the Amex FHR program, no worries, because I thought they might be reading me for an upgrade. Nope, not the case. I moved from a fabulous suite in my previous hotel to the highest level room (that I booked), no upgrade. So, as the check-in staff is singing me the praises of the room that I booked, I'm silently stewing and wanting to run back to my previous accommodations. How are we to survive in this room for 2 nights, I wondered?No withstanding the fact that I didn't get an upgrade, I did discover some pleasures and comforts. The view from the room was majestic - from the 37th floor, you could view Tokyo in a whole new perspective. The shower was incredible, spacious, great water pressure, and had its own stunning view of the city. I loved the bath toiletries (Aman brand) and the welcome chocolates, and min-fridge sodas (we didn't have any, but loved having the option). The bath robe was extremely comfortable and I used it throughout the day. The bed however, was exceptionally uncomfortable and I probably couldn't have tolerated it beyond the 2 nights. There was nothing really special about the room besides the view and the shower (which gets the highest awards). The heated bathroom floor made the room temp uncomfortable in July). On night 2, I realized that our room wasn't totally ready when we checked in because we received new stuff at turn down - herbs for the bath, good night message card in bamboo sleeve, etc. wish I had the herbs on night 1, could have made use of them - oh well.Throughout our visit, I felt like we were being watched in the creepiest kind of way. We didn't make a move without someone stumbling over us to ask, "can I help you" or my interpretation of "where do you think you are going/doing". At Peninsula, I felt cared for, here I felt the property was king, it was cared for.What I did enjoy was the food. Although the reviews on food have been mediocre, I found the offerings fabulous. Breakfast was delicious each morning - the freshest fruit I've ever had. Service needs some attention as previously reported, but the food was great and thoughtfully presented. We tried the "Black Bar" one evening, but it fell short because the menu of cocktails lacked description. Paying $26+ for a drink titled Black Magic without any idea of its constituents is not my idea of a good time or way to spen my money. The bartender kindly described each of the 15+ drinks for me, but that is just nonsense - when I wanted to reorder, I couldn't remember any of that and just decided not too - ending the evening frustrated versus enlightened.I also found the common spaces very attractive and easy to relax in - this was a plus for Aman. The gym was quite nice, spacious, with great equipment. Yet, the gym refreshments didn't show up until I was leaving on the last morning. The Japanese blueberry was a delicious and refreshing post work-out treat- wish I'd had that on my first morning. Oh well, lot's of wishes.I arranged transportation services from the hotel to the airport and the cost was well beyond that quoted from other luxury properties in the area - no Rolls on this trip, just your regular old taxi...at a Rolls fee.There are elements of Aman Tokyo that I adored, public spaces, the dining room, breakfast offerings and prep, the gym equipment and space, the spa appearance (canceled appointment when I discovered I was getting what I paid for, nothing more), my shower, and the view. But I didn't depart with that "cared for" feeling, something that makes a property truly exclusive, not the price tag. A property with an ethos around wellness should do this better than anyone else and this property doesn't.

review_body: As this was the first Aman resort we’ve stayed in, expectations were high. Fortunately, Aman Tokyo did not disappoint! In fact, it exceeded our high expectations. As we were traveling with a large family group of seven, we asked for three contiguous rooms on a non-smoking floor. Fortunately, the Aman was able to oblige. Although we booked the rooms through Amex Fine Hotels & Resorts, this constraint meant they weren’t able to accommodate an upgrade. No matter - the rooms were incredibly spacious and well-designed. The decor of the Aman Tokyo is modern Japanese. It’s very muted, serene - done in slate and natural woods. Everything is well designed and ergonomic. The layout of the room is really genius: a desk area at the “top” of the room, the bedding and side tables in the middle, and at the “foot” of the room a seating area and banquette / daybed along the windows. It really works and provides “micro-environments” that optimize the space. The view we had (over-looking the Imperial Gardens) was spectacular, especially on the clear nights. The desk design was great, and the audio-visual worked flawlessly (I used both a Chromecast through the HDMI input, and also used the in-room Bose speaker via Bluetooth.) The controls by the nightstands at the head of the bed were well designed, well-labeled and operated the rooms lighting, blackout curtains and temperature controls. (And the blackout curtains worked exceptionally well - crucial since the sun rose at around 4:30am this time of year.) One slight complaint - the remote control for the TV was strictly Japanese and complicated. Took some trial and error to figure it out. The Wifi was free and fast.  The bed and bedding was comfortable, although it was clear that the king-sized bed was actually two mattresses with a seam between them. As seams go, it was tolerable. The bathroom too was well designed. The Neorest washlet was amazing - the toilet raised and lowered its lid (and flushed) automatically. There was a two-headed shower, with both wand and “rain” showerheads. Floors were heated and there was a great set of shampoos and amenities, as well a great towels and robes. The Japanese soaking tub was a welcome relief at the end of long days. The FHR benefits included breakfast, which we utilized every day. Breakfast was fantastic, and options included a Japanese set breakfast, or varieties of western options including pancakes, waffles, eggs, bagels, yogurt, etc. The waitstaff were efficient and kind, and the food was delicious. We utilized room service several times, and it was also fast, hot, and delicious.  We didn’t utilize the lobby much, but it was always a delight to re-enter that serene space after a busy day in the Tokyo streets and subways. We occasionally used the Library (which is a great space) as a gathering point. The pool is truly amazing - on the 33 Floor with panoramic views of the Tokyo skyline. The pool room was quite hot and the water quite warm - both of which suit me - but possibly too intense for some. My wife used the yoga room several times, which she said was amongst the best spaces she’d seen in a hotel.We began using the concierge services well before our visit and the team certainly worked hard on our behalf. In addition to restaurant reservations, they helped us with a tour of Kamakura and an outing to a local baseball game. They were efficient and able to arrange all of this via email, which was our preferred means of communication. We found the location of the hotel (literally on top of underground access to both Tokyo Station and Otemachi Station) to be ideal. After a week in the Aman Tokyo, I can say it’s surely amongst our favorite hotels in the world. It’s really well designed, thoughtful, balanced, appropriate and understated. There are perhaps “fancier” hotels, but the “zen” simplicity of the Aman really won us over. We will be back!

This hotel is clearly the best in Tokyo, as a food traveler, Tokyo, is a place we go often, we have stayed at The Peninsula, The Four Seasons and the Mandarin. I believe the Aman is in a whole different level. But, the concierge clearly thinks lacks experience. Twice we asked her to help us in different but very simple matters, twice she failed. I suggest you change the concierge team S.A.P. They clearly can ruin the whole experience that I know is very important to the whole staff.

A beautiful 87 rooms upscale hotel located in the top 6 floors of the Otemachi tower near the imperial gardens. The facilities (beautiful lobby, oversized lap pool, gym, spa, Japanese bath, library, restaurants...) and rooms (ours was facing the imperial gardens) are super beautiful and the Aman Tokyo could potentially play at the top of the Tokyo luxury hotels league......However: 1- In our room, the electric shades stoped working on day 2 and we had to spend a night without windows black-out. 2- At the restaurant, I waited 35mn the first day at breakfast for a white omelette and no one would offer me coffee refill. On the second day, I asked for one hard boiled egg and one soft boiled egg and the waiter said it was not possible. Even at classic business 4* hotels I was able to get this. Unbelievable. Also the restaurant staff is clearly untrained as they seem to go around inefficiently (the staff outnumbers the guests yet no one is there to clear the table or offer water or coffee refills). 3- Finally, in a very strange fashion, when you enter or exit the hotel, sometimes the staff is there to greet you with a cheer or assist you, and other time they ignore you perfectly - almost as if you were transparent. Very inconsistent.We were just at the 4 seasons Kyoto before staying at the Aman Tokyo, and clearly the Aman has a lot of work and training to do in order to catch up with the seamless, perfect service at a four seasons.Will not stay there again.

We recently finished a 2 week trip to Japan with our last few nights at the Aman Tokyo. It was one of the anticipated highlights of our trip being able to stay at one of the most revered properties in the city. It did not disappoint. Located on the 33rd floor of the Otemachi Tower, we exited the elevator into a grand space that was created to give a sense of spacial openness while also showcasing the views of Tokyo through it's panoramic floor to ceiling glass windows. The checkin process was very smooth and easy. Our rooms were beautifully appointed showcasing the heights of corporate hotel/resort design. The showers and baths overlooking the city through a floor to ceiling glass view was nothing shy of amazing. The staff was amongst the best we encountered during our stay, and graciously helped us with every request and need. Our only dings on the property were some mild scuffs on the walls of our room, which upon reporting this to the manager, was immediately cleaned up. The breakfast was also disappointing, feeling very skimpy on the items ordered. For the hefty cost of our breakfast, they easily could have provided a better experience here. And we were shocked to see that in today's age (2017), the Aman Tokyo actually offered an entire smoking floor?! Seriously? That in our view was an extremely bad decision on their part, and showed very poor judgement when the majority of "exclusive high end" resorts and hotels in most developed countries now ban smoking entirely from the premises. There's simply no up-side to offering smoking rooms no days. Smokers can go outside to do something that's offensive to most and leaves a lasting smell in the walls and rooms. But other than those few complaints, the staff and the management went out of their way to make sure our stay was the best it could be, and the design and architecture of the property is by far the best you can find in Tokyo (we've previously stayed at the Ritz Tokyo among others, and this bested them all). We would happily return and would recommend this property to anyone who wants to have spectacular views of Tokyo during their stay matched with an incredibly designed experience.

Service can be so great in Tokyo - in this hotel it is above average, but not great. Rooms are large and all hard surfaced which makes them echo-y... every sound in the toilet can be heard everywhere in the room (so if you are jet-lagged or a light sleeper and traveling with someone else, beware) The rooms do have very good sound-proofing of outside noise tho. You'd never know you're in the city -- and never heard anyone in the hallway.I've stayed in every good and great hotel in Tokyo over years of doing business here, and this is not worth double or triple or quadruple the price of those places. Great location however. Food, again, is average but certainly not great. I would stick with Western food. The Japan food was mediocre -- go to the restaurants in the basement of the building for MUCH better food. The 33rd floor lobby is spectacular, but more suited to the public using it, than to hotel guests feeling cocooned and feeling specially treated.I've stayed in many Amans around the world (for 25 years!) and loved them. This did not feel like that. Service was just slightly off almost every interaction... and that is not my experience in the good and great Tokyo hotels where I will continue staying on my future trips to Japan.

Loved this hotel ... everything about this property resonates with serenity ....the views of Tokyo... Emporia's palace...it's just amazing... the Spa is so authentically Japanese....literally all issues of life just 'drop off' at the entrance of the Spa...! The food and wine selection is just too perfectly selected to keep you entertained with the serene ambience of this magnificent property... it's just too good!

Endlessly helpful. When we were leaving, we were unsure which platform we needed to take from at Tokyo station. They sent a young man with us, in the hotel car, all without charge to point us in the right direction. Really appreciated!

Already a few times in Tokyo, I chose to stay in this Aman regardless of its seemingly high price. Tokyo is always a tricky place for high end hotels. Places like Park Hyatt, Ritz Carlton and Palace Imperial seem like staying behind of the new trend of hotel standard. Their rooms stink of old cigarettes. The Lobbies are tiny and look a bit reserved. The service is more the feeling of yes this is obligatory rather than personal.Aman Tokyo is one of a few city hotels in their collection. It is not really a business hotel. During my stay I could hardly see one's portfolio discussed over the table, nor some deal making dinners. People here seem relaxed, casual yet stylish. It is, however, not a resort hideaway like most of other Amens. The facilities here, tough all of top quality, are not self sufficient enough for guests to stay in the hotel during the stay. For example, while the library contains a good selection of books, one could hardly enjoy quietly the offerings as food and drinks are provided there as well. There are 2 restaurants- one in the Lobby area where breakfast and Italian food is served. The Aman Cafe near the entrance on the ground level offers casual French bistro food and crepe. Mind you, there will be many outside guests- we had to wait to be seated several times. The room design, with the emphasis on wood, paper and stone, is a great bland of contemporary and Japanese tradition. The writing desk, the bed, and the sitting area are all facing the same direction that is looking over the palace. The pool is really the highlight of the hotel. I am not a big fan of some hotels' choice of putting standard pools with swimming lanes, as however ok I am as a swimmer, I am usually not planning to improve my swimming gestures, nor my speed for a lap, during my stay in hotels. I prefer somewhere I could relax, somewhere I could swim a bit, while enjoying the good surrounding. The pool here ticks all the boxes. It is long enough to have a good lap. It is well designed so that your mind is calmed once you stepped into the pool area. You have a great view for the sunset. The only slight complain is the training of the staff in the main restaurant during breakfast. Coffee was served without sugar. We ordered twice a latte, the first time came a regular coffee with milk on the side, the second a more normal latte with mixed scotched milk and coffee. One may decide on its house style of latte, but be consistent and don't serve different things under the same name. Also first day bread was served with jams, the second without. These are really small things which don't affect your enjoyment of the meal, but it is an initial alarm for the management to better implement its service standard.I think this hotel is outstanding in the limited luxury Hotel offering in Tokyo andI will definitely come back to Aman Tokyo.

I have been to Tokyo many times for work and vacation. First time staying at the Aman Tokyo. This time around it was just 3 nights in Tokyo for a bunch of meetings and then back home. The property is well located to many of the large financial institutions, the rooms are large and comfortable and the staff was on point for everything. I've read a couple reviews about the food being sub-par, I totally disagree. The restaurant was great (had 3 breakfasts and 1 lunch there) and the staff was accurate and efficient. I will be staying there again next time I need to be in Tokyo for work. A note to the families considering the Aman Tokyo, if you have young children (under 12), I would suggest another hotel in the area. While I loved my stay there (and I have very young children), many of the amenities, such as the gorgeous pool are off-limits to anyone under the age of 18. I understand the rule, but if my kids saw that pool, I don't think they could resist jumping in (and I might just let them :) !!!).

Aman is always Aman! Everything is perfect at Aman Tokyo. The top is the view from the suites. We changed two and both had incredible views! Really impressive. Service is perfect and everything seems to be perfect. I don't give the maximum because I noticed that in the hall of the hotel there was always too much people. It was really too much crowded and noisy, specially considering the Aman concept. Anyway fantastic hotel!

The Aman is in every respect a superb hotel to stay when in Tokyo. It is a top stylish place, well managed and everyone is extremely friendly and accommodating. The spa treatment is top and the pool area large and spacious. We stayed twice there (March & April) and would definitely go back on a future visit to Japan.

What a fantastic, unique property. This was the first Aman I had stayed at, and we made the journey for a weekend from Hong Kong to meet up with my family who were traveling in Japan at the time (my aunt is a Virtuoso travel agent and they picked here).It really is a tranquil urban oasis. You're located right in one of the core business districts of Tokyo, but would never know it if you didn't look outside.The rooms are incredible. Traditional Japanese style and elegance, but with modern finishes. The bathroom is amazing, particularly being able to look out into the city from the bathtub.The pool and spa area are phenomenal; the level of zen there is truly an almost out-of-body experience.The main restaurant was good, but it is always a little disappointing when restaurants don't feature the local cuisine (so don't expect sushi)!Definitely the best hotel in Tokyo, and one of the best "hotel" (not resort, villas, etc.) there is.

Back in 1968 I walked into the Okura in Tokyo and thought finally a city hotel that understands how to blend what is wonderful about Japan with the needs of the time. It was a majical place. Its glory days are long gone but finally another hotel has stepped forward to take its place. The Aman is outstanding. It gets the simplicity of Japanese design, the elegance and the special warmth within a paired down environment.The public rooms are spectacular, the bedrooms perfect. The views over the Imperial palace could not be better and the location is ideal. You have to visit the pool and marvel at it size and when I was there I was their no one else swimming. Too bad as it is a marvel. The food is quite good but the service a bit confused at times. Nothing confused about the welcome and the effort the staff goes to in order to make your stay special..Aman has done it again. Peace and tranquility and this time in a large office block in one of the busiest cities in the world....congratulations.(one thing I would caution the guest about. the bedrooms have two levels. One for the bed and the other a sitting area. Both great but the floors are all the same wood and stained the same light color so if you are not careful its easy to miss a step and end up on the floor. They should stain the last wood board before the step a darker color to help you notice...small point)

The Aman Tokyo is spectacular. You realize you are in a special place when you walk into the stunning, multi-story atrium. It is a marvel of modern design and frankly hard to understand why they would choose to waste so much open space inside of a high end office tower in the center of Tokyo. But that's not your problem -- you can marvel and enjoy.The rooms are a combination of traditional Japanese style with the most modern technology. They are incredibly comfortable and have stunning view of the skyline and the Imperial Palace if you are lucky. The baths are unbelievable, with the Japanese tub right near the window. You can sit back and enjoy the most amazing view.Breakfasts are excellent, giving you choices of both western and Japanese. And the concierge is largely helpful getting reservations at some of the best restaurants in Tokyo.My massage in the gorgeous spa was spectacular. Very high quality and deep tissue. The gym is decent and there is a pool (35 floors above Tokyo!)My only criticism is of lunch and dinner. They are not as good as they could be. Not sure the restaurant is all that good beyond breakfast. Though the bar is amazingly beautiful -- great drinks and great views. But these are minor quibbles. The Tokyo Aman is one of the best hotels in the world. Splurge!

Wow! Can I say it again? Wow! Wow!This hotel is just ridiculously amazing.I have stayed there for four nights and had two rooms.The SPA - incredible. Take your time and book a facial or a massage. It is amazing.The overall service - housekeeping, concierge, dining, in room dining, basically everywhere - superb!I also enjoyed the afternoon tea at the lobby and the bar at night.The rooms - beautiful, clean, modern, with perfect blackout shades, and super comfortable beds.I can't wait to go back. It was just perfect!

Great position, not far from the Imperial garden and easy access to the metro. Excellent service (despite some weakness in speaking english), with a special mention for the breakfast served in the room: simply perfect. But the top are the rooms: with full glass windows, you can overlook the skyline and the imperial palace (during the night a breathtaking experience). And especially the interior design, the quality of details and furnitures, really outstanding. After all, Aman is always Aman....

The hotel is wonderful; the location is great; the rooms are spacious with beautiful views; the service is outstanding. One big disappointment is the concierge service. Tokyo restaurants that I chose myself were great (sushi Sawada, sushi Giro, Joel Robuchon). Everything the concierge recommended was of a very POOR quality. One of the examples is Sushi-ko Honten restaurant. Even a 2nd rate London or Paris Japanese restaurant serves better quality sushi and sashimi. So double-check before you accept the recommendations of the Aman Tokyo concierge!

Just spent 5 glorious days & nights in this amazing hotel.The scale of the hotel provides tranquility and ambience whilst overlooking the imperial palace & skyline of Tokyo.Impeccable service & food. Breakfast was a feast of Japanese or American choice overseen by Gerard. Eggs Benedict are to die for!!Can't wait to go back!!

Great premier room facing the Tokyo Sky Tree and sunrise, amazing breakfast served in the room daily. Super efficient and helpful concierge team who were able to book last minute restaurants, and pottery class. Pool and gym are spectacular. Gym and locker rooms don't allow folks under 18. Hotel staff couldn't be more helpful and efficient. Kids felt welcomed and atmosphere is relaxed given it's high end positioning. Location is in the Otemachi business district. Not an issue for us. Short walk to Imperial Gardens. Ginza a bit of a longer walk. Hotel sits on top of the Metro station and a quick walk to Tokyo Station. For us location was ideal. Would go back and recommend highly.

Second trip to Aman Tokyo. Great location, attentive, yet unobtrusive staff. Love the large, uncrowded spaces. It's not inexpensive, but worth it for privacy, exclusivity and luxury. Literally only positive things to say about bar, lounge, room service, room facilities, fitness center. Perhaps my favorite hotel in the world.

The Aman Tokyo is a relatively recent addition to the Aman group of luxury hotels and is stunningly beautiful with classic, understated elegance. Starting with the lobby on the 33rd floor with an atrium ceiling that must be 100' high looming over the central area, and with glass walls providing wonderful views over Tokyo and, on a clear day, Mt. Fuji in the distance, every aspect of the design is as close to perfection as one can come. During our stay,the centre of the lounge area contained a huge vase with beautiful cherry tree branches in full bloom. (A photo op for almost everyone who passed through the lounge area.) A restaurant, bar, "humidor", library etc.surround two sides.The guest rooms are on floors 34-38, and our suite on the 38th floor was vast, with a very large bed room with separate sitting area overlooking the city, a huge bathroom in black granite with a separate room overlooking Tokyo containing a huge onsen to soak in while dreaming.The living room, linked to the bedroom by a large entry hall ,was once again vast and contained a separate service kitchen, dining table, office and a large corner lounge area overlooking views in two directions and containing a sofa, chairs and a settee. Beautiful "blonde" wood floors and furniture upholstered in a handsome dark fabric add to the beauty.All in all, one of the most elegant suites that we have ever stayed in.While we did not have a chance to sample the spa, from the reports that we have heard it is likewise perfection and includes a large indoor pool as well as the usual spa features.The staff is welcoming and, in contrast to many other Japanese hotels, is quite conversant in English.Judging by the level of activity, the bar and lounge area appear to have become a "destination" for non-hotel guests and, based on our sampling, the bartenders mix superb martinis.

What a hotel! The minute you arrive you feel pampered and welcomed. The rooms are immaculate and the design oh my god. It is quite new that's true; which helps! The concierge staff is super super efficient. They deserve a special mention because they manage to book all the restaurants I asked for. Couldn't be more thankful. It was the first stop during my honeymoon and they really went over the top; even giving us a room upgrade. Will be going back to Tokyo this year and staying there for sure!

Just back from our first trip to the Aman Tokyo, and this hotel has transformed us into Aman junkies. Wow. My partner and I can be jaded travelers- I formerly worked in operations for one of the world's top tour companies, so I've seen it all when it comes to fine hotels, and the two of us have racked up stays in countless luxury properties around the globe. But the Aman Tokyo truly sets a new standard for hospitality, room design, and effortless elegance and comfort. The property is stunning, from the dramatic lobby to the serene pool to the plushly-stocked spa area. Service is gracious and warm, with staff members who welcome you "home" each time you return to the hotel. And it indeed feels like home from the moment you check in- the rooms are modern and luxuriously spare, with ingenious decor features like a compartment that disguises the TV (is there anything more foul than a widescreen marring an otherwise chic room?), heated floors in the bathroom (essential) and a built-in window seat that beckons you to lounge and gaze at the Tokyo skyline for hours. Oh, and the rooms are lit so impeccably that they'd make Quasimodo look like Ryan Gosling. The basalt tub in our Premier Room was a major highlight of our stay- we spent hours looking at the city lights and drinking tea while immersed in the yuzu-scented bathwater. We also appreciated touches like nightly snack deliveries of fresh rice crackers and yummy Japanese sweets. We didn't eat dinner or lunch at the restaurant, but courtesy of jet lag we stopped by the Bar on our first night at the hotel and my partner had a delectable green tea cocktail (my milk tea cocktail was solid though less impressive). We also enjoyed full Japanese breakfast at the Restaurant- it was beautifully presented and delicious, and the server kindly honored my request for no fish by substituting a spread of vegetables. One tiny quibble with an otherwise extraordinary experience: we found the service at the Aman to be somewhat less efficient than the service at comparable Tokyo hotels (such as the Park Hyatt). Breakfast service, for instance, can be somewhat slow and inconsistent, and I can see the the check-in/check-out service feeling slow if you are accustomed to the rapid-fire pace of a more business-oriented hotel (though as leisure travelers, we enjoyed the process and thought the staff were excellent). I also found the Concierge to be not quite on par with the rest of the service. Even the simple request of a surprise gift of chocolates for my partner took numerous exchanges and calls and felt more complicated than it should have (not to mention that they ruined the surprise by bringing the chocolates to the door and handing them directly to him, instead of leaving the box at turndown as we'd agreed). But if the Aman Tokyo adjusts their few service quirks, and perhaps improves their concierge staff, they will be unstoppable. In any case, they have made us into lifetime devotees. We're returning to Tokyo in a few months and we'll definitely be booking a few nights at our new "home"- the Aman.
