review_body: Location: Great Location short walk to Otemachi Subway and Tokyo station. Narita airport limousine bus direct to the door step. Lobby floor on 33 floor of the Otemachi Tower. Very central for Business and Leisure travelers. Shopping is just across the street.Service: Overall service is hospitable and attentive. Esp the Bell staff. At times at the restaurant for breakfast, the service is lacking or it is a bit too busy. Concierge could be more knowledgeable in restaurants recommendations given many are frequent guests to Tokyo. Room: The suite we had was spacious with a stunning view of Tokyo. The décor is sleek, modern and stone & wood with a tint of Japanese element. Some may find it not grand. The beds are placed in the way that you could enjoy the sweeping view of Tokyo. Since it's a business trip, we did not have ample free time to enjoy the spacious suite.Enjoyed having a spacious bathroom and the soaking tub commanding a panoramic view from the floor to ceiling window.The restaurant featured a designated farm eggs that were perfectly cooked. Service could be more detailed if sufficient staff during breakfast time.The sunlight shining through flashing on the lobby lounge is like a light show. Interesting.. Rate is high, yet for the prestigious address, one must experience at least once.

Tokyo's new Aman features what is probably the capital's most magnificent hotel hardware; like the room charges, it's a breath taking experience every inch of the way. The predominant colors are gray slate and light woods, in sleek, ultra contemporary designs that display dramatic whimsy with extraordinarily effective restraint. It's a novel salute to Japanese aesthetics by people with erudite tastes who are not Japanese, so it feels creative, despite the often dead-end sukiyazukuri minimalism inherent in much Japanese design. There appears little is visible that is not functional, but it nonetheless strikes one as utterly gorgeous, due to its restrained design and unabashedly lavish usage of what may be Japan's most valuable commodity: space. The guest room was elegantly uncluttered in appearance but richly appointed; the bath simple yet heavenly. The sinfully spacious, visually engaging corridors impress, as does the lobby. But it's the views from walls of windows that save the interiors from being merely svelte and contemporary. It's Japan From Foreign Eyes, not at all authentic, but fresh. The floral arrangements in the room were simply bits of bushes plopped into a frogless container inside a handsome fake basket. Not ikebana but who cares? They made you reexamine little sprigs of nature. Aman Tokyo has a few big failures, the first being the food in a city famous for go-for-broke eating out. The staff uniforms are humorous redeployments of local traditional clothing. And many of the staff, many of whom were not Japanese but in menial jobs, seem untrained so service is uneven, and therefore sometimes shockingly uncharacteristic of Japanese standards. But with such a quietly opulent interior and those endless views of glittering Tokyo, and a pool made on high, the flaws seem minimal and forgivable. But bring money and be prepared not to whimper when you get your bills. Business executives will not stay here, and it probably isn't a good location for first hand encounters with Japanese life, but if you can afford it once or twice, it's a very beautiful, interesting spot to stay.

the hotel is very expensive, but worth the price for a nice getaway! the rooms are so spacious, beautifully decorated, onsen style bath in each bathroom, you receive personalized turn down at the end of every day, a letter, or something that will make you feel at home.

Soaring above Tokyo skyline, centrally located, magnificent reception atrium and very spacious rooms with incredible views. Still suffering from a few service teething problems it is backed up by phenomenal management such as Gérard Eady and Yusuku Saito to smooth things over. The food in the restaurant is worthy of a Michelin star and in room dining is solid but unexciting. It could do with a restaurant with a more comprehensive menu for lighter meals at more reasonable prices as eating every night in main restaurant is too expensive. Also the prices in the spa were pretty well double what we paid at the Ritz Carlton in Kyoto so seem way over the top. Overall a stunning hotel that in time will be a #1 city hotel. Loved it. We are Aman junkies!

I loved this hotel. The welcome is great, the room fantastic with views over Tokyo. Great decor of simple and clean lines. Deep bath in the window with the same view. Staff excellent and food delicious. As with all Aman hotels there is a different feel to other hotels, calm and peaceful.

Having been to more than 20 Amans, I was very excited to stay in the first AMAN city hotel. Overall experience was a positive one, the room and hotel architecture is truly a strong point resulting in you wanting to spend most of your time within the property. Job well done by Kerry Hill architects. Pros- room and hotel architecture is excellent, efficient use of space maintaining practicality with aesthetics, lobby and pool area is spectacularly exceptional- arrival and checkin was very smooth and did an excellent job to immediately identify us by our last name upon arrival- Gym is spacious and well equipped- library and cigar bar area is beautiful with floor to height ceiling of at least around 12 metersCons- restaurant service was slow; took more Than 1hr to serve breakfast, Well mannered but slow.- quality of food in the restaurant was mediocre, service was slightly flustered - not the typical calm and assuring manner that AMAN is known for- location of hotel is not "ideal" if you would like to dine in Roppongi restaurants; it is a good 20-25 mins away by taxi - property has around 85 rooms, slightly disappointed that they couldn't address hotel guests by their last names. This has always been a plus point in an AMAN where all service staff addresses hotel guests by their last name and recognize their room number (and therefore no clumsy signing of the bill after a meal).

My husband and I spent our honeymoon at one of the super amazing corner suite for 5 nights in last November and we were more than impressed! I actually think I am lost in words to describe how incredible Aman Tokyo is. Every single thing was so detail oriented and up to the best standard possible. We especially enjoyed the spacious suite, the 6 stars amenities, the heavenly bed, the professional services, and of course the spa! The resting lounge at the spa is so wonderfully designed where you enjoy the best Tokyo view with a nice cup of hot Japanese tea. The spa treatment using essential oils originated from Japan was another highlight and the therapist did an amazing job. We actually had three treatments during our entire visit. Only thing that I would like them to take note is probably the quality of room service. The food was alright but not great. I would expect something very delicious if staying in such a nice hotel. We didn't get to try the hotel restaurant because the room service wasn't impressive enough. But we will definitely be back in the future for sure :)

When we checked into the hotel, the hotel was noisy and packed. Most of the staff seem to act 'professional' and we cant feel the genuine service from them. Nevertheless, the room was beautiful and spacious. We enjoyed the room. It was high tech and neat. I would like to thank Mai AIDA for helping us to recommend a few dinner place and also place reservation for us. Her genuine service is something that will make us go back again.

We just stayed at the Aman Tokyo for 3 nights, marking the end of our 2+week trip through South East Asia (+Japan). What a great way to end the trip. The lobby of the hotel is on the 33rd floor of the Otemachi Tower, and from the outside it looks fairly understated. Once we arrived at the 33rd floor and walk into the lobby, we were overwhelmed by the beauty and design! It's a 5 story atrium, with the upper levels made up of rice paper. The design of our room was pretty amazing, and considering the small spaces you always hear Tokyo is famous for, it was pretty massive, with the main bedroom, the large bathroom, and an entire adjoining living room/second half bathroom. Throughout, the design was a modern / contemporary mixed in with the traditional, and the quality was just wonderful.The service and attentiveness of the staff throughout our entire stay was phenomenal, the amenities were wonderful, the pool is one of the most beautiful I've seen, and the spa was great. The food was also excellent, and the bar was a good place to grab drinks at the end of the night. We had a wonderful stay and this hotel is one of the best experiences we've had.

Let us simply say that this is our number one favourite hotel in the world! We have been to many Amans worldwide and this one, their first urban property marks an exciting new development for Aman. A ten plus plus!

Been looking forward to staying at Aman Tokyo. Was unable to on my last trip as they were still under renovations. Aman felt like a modern ryokan. There was the public bath (onsen) available at the Spa for guest to use and the large pool which was most of the time unused. Love that the water was warm in winter unlike other 5 star hotels I've stayed at in Tokyo.Limousine bus from Narita airport would alight you straight at the hotel which is a plus(we had a lot of baggages) a taxi wouldn't even be enough to accommodate all our luggage.What made my trip most memorable at Aman is the breathtaking views from almost every corner of the hotel. Right from the lobby, to the Spa, the pool, the bathroom and my own deluxe room. It is probably one of the most quiet hotel in the city I've stayed at which is a plus. No wonder they say that Aman Tokyo is an urban sanctuary.Would love to come back soon !

The lobby takes your breath away. 4-Story washi paper ceiling of lobby allows you the sensation of being inside a Japanese lantern. The Aman Tokyo combines the elegant, simplicity of Japanese culture with the high end luxury of Aman Resorts... Incredible! At the very least go up to the Aman Tokyo for High Tea and enjoy the views... or start your evening out with a drink in their lobby bar. Such a unique experience. Enjoy!

The hotel is designed to be a resort at the center of Tokyo. It is at the top floors of an office building near the Tokyo Station. This is of course a luxury and it is also priced as such. So I had higher expectation accordingly. I stayed there twice with one night each. Both stays were excellent, but somehow missing a wow.The room was spacious with a good view of the palace area, and Mt Fuji further away. It is nicely decorated as a resort room. Unfortunately the room is not kid or elderly friendly. The are corners on many furnitures and it is easy to hit one's head on something. There are three steps in the middle if the room, which I think is designed to separate the sleeping area and living area.The area is very quiet at night as it is in the business district. Transportation is convenient as it is close to both the subway and the JR train station. It is just a few minutes to Ginza by taxi.Breakfast was good. The staff was helpful. Given some of the negative comments on their service before, they are improving.

It's strange reading some of the eccentric and clueless comments here. The woman from Hong Kong who claims "no-one" in the restaurant understands English - I didn't have that problem with a single staff member, and I am - as it happens - English. They all spoke English perfectly fine. And yes, they understood the word "milk". Duh. The guy from Kuwait who says the Japanese are "just the way they are" with service - no, guy from Kuwait, Japan has the best service on the planet and no, they don't need training from Americans, who these days have some of the worst. You just have to adapt a little bit, maybe, but not very much. The location you can *research* before you arrive, so if the ten minute walk to the "shopping streets" ( whatever that means in Tokyo ) is too much, you can factor that in. Most Tokyo shopping is spread out over an area larger than the Emirates, so it's a meaningless complaint anyway. Otemachi is in the north end of Ginza, smack in the middle of the world's largest metropolis. So no, you don't get to go walkies everywhere because it's a city of 35 million people. Got that? As for the hotel, it's pretty much faultless unless you're a walking zombie. True, you get to eat much cheaper at thousands of other places in the gastronomic capital of the world, but then you don't get to look at Mount Fuji fading into the dusk and flop into your room directly afterwards. It's this thing called *hotel prices* which you already know about. If you are fazed by hotel prices, then you eat outside the hotel : voila! How simple it is! As for rooms not being ready at 9am, well, if they're full they're full - are they going to turf people out into the street because you have an early flight? Yes, frustrating, but there you are. It's the same everywhere unless the hotel has an empty room. Boom. As for the Aman : fantastic rooms with private stone onsets, gorgeous public onsen ( largely empty because the foreigners don't know what an onsen is ), soaring lobby made of traditional paper, amazing city views ( and the aforementioned Fuji ) and impeccable service. Not good enough? Okay, I feel for you. Life is tough.

Aman Tokyo is a very luxurious Hotel. Every detail is designed carefully, and the rooms are very spacious according to Tokyo Standards. The room and the bathroom are extremely modern. The floors are heated, and the toilet seat is state of art. The window drapes would make the room absolutely dark. The view from the high floor room is exceptional. It is not a child friendly room though, as all of the furniture edges are little sharp.The restaurant and room service food are excellent, but overpriced. It is a pity that the room rate does not include breakfast too.The hotel staff are working to their potentials, and trying their best to assist us. The problem with Japanese people is that they are not very well accustomed with any other culture. Also most of them don't speak any language besides Japanese. They are very friendly, and they try to help you anywhere, anytime, and anyhow. The hotel staff seems to have memorized the manual very well, but they can't interact accordingly. If I ever want to change something from the menu, they would panic and would not do it correctly. I can't complain, because I know that this is their potential, and that this is the way they are! I recommend to get an outside training company (preferably American) and train all of the staff in a very intensified training course. It would really make a big difference. I like the idea of making a separate hotel entrance with specialized staff at the Ground level of the Otemachi Building. I also liked the direct non-stop elevator to the Hotel lobby on the 33rd floor.I didn't like the way the front desk is designed. It is right in front of the elevator, and looks like an office reception. I recommend moving it to another location away from the elevator, and redesigning it to more hotel-like reception check in area. Also the concierge is located in a very far secluded corner, and I suggest keeping both Reception and concierge close to each other.I had an incident with the hotel that I didn't like. My long 8 hours overnight flight arrived at Narita airport early in the morning. I have sent several emails to the hotel prior to my arrival stating that I would like my room to be ready by 9 a.m. The hotel informed me that they are at full capacity, and they will try their best to accommodate my room. When I arrived with my family, they said that the room won't be ready until 12 p.m. I was frustrated provided that I have given them a notice. The manager gave me the model room. It was a quick solution, but I was expecting a better service for staying at a very pricey high end hotel! They would not have done anything if I have not been upset. My point is that these basic mistakes should not happen in a resort like The Aman Chain.I believe by now you see the need for my training recommendation.The hotel location is a bit secluded, and far from the main shopping areas. Some people may want that seclusion, but as for my family, it is a far walk. The taxis are available everywhere though, and the Otemachi tower has its own restaurants and shops too.Overall, Aman is very overpriced for the service level they have. I wish that they would match the other Aman Resorts service standards. Best of Luck

The following unpleasant experiences to share: (1) when making reservation months ago we requested early check-in. Hotel as usual replied difficult but promised to make last minutes effort upon our arrival. However, when arrived, lobby reception did not even ask my name, just replied in those non-caring official wordings...."...our check-in time is after 3 p.m. please leave your bags and come back at 3 p.m.....thank you....." Did they know their promise to me months ago to help upon arrival?! (2) so, no choice, disappointing with their dishonest promise to help customer, we did check-in after 3 p.m. Soon thereafter, the room bell rang and the staff requested to get back a guest coat left inside the room that does not belong to me, so horrifying....the room still hanging other guest's property! (3) staff at restaurant cannot understood English. They did not even understand what "Milk" is. Unbelievable; (4) upon receipt my credit card statement after return home, I discovered my card was debited wrongly and refunded again without my approval and acknowledgement. As a result, I have to suffer exchange loss on this unauthorized transaction. I wrote to voice my complaints to the Hotel. The response was all superficial, admitting making unauthorized use of my credit card, expressed apology, and welcome me again for improved services next time.....Sorry, this is just superficial without a "heart" and sincere attitude to compensate or regain confidence of customers. Everyone, just too real cases to share with you all. Most important of all, take good care of your credit card!

The first metropolitan Aman property does not disappoint. Every single aspect of Aman Tokyo oozes minimalist luxury: stellar yet discrete service, impeccable zen design, high end amenities...You know you're about to experience something special as soon as you step into the grand lobby. The hotel perfectly combines traditional Japanese design with modern minimalism to create quite a unique result. One caveat: design lovers will love Kerry Hill's work, but its extensive use of dark stone and straight lines may be perceived as austere. The rooms are all very bright nevertheless.The gym is very well equipped and the pool boasts stunning views of the city. The restaurant is OK, but nothing to rave about. In fact, I found it quite disappointing, especially in a city with such a great food offering. The breakfast made up for it though (don't hesitate to order room service, the rooms are set up so that one can enjoy beautiful views Overall, this hotel is perfect for both business and leisure, when traveling solo or as a couple. It is, however, not necessarily the best place to stay for families with young children.

For many years the Park Hyatt Tokyo has been our home away from home in Japan, a refuge in times of jet-lagged disorientation immortalized in Sophia Coppola's 'Lost in Translation'. Indeed, before arriving at Aman Tokyo, we felt the need to spend our first night at the Park Hyatt, from where we took a taxi to the Aman, where we were greeted by name as the taxi door opened (just one of the inexplicable wonders in Japan's finest hotels). Others have rightly described the soaring lobby, the huge (for Tokyo) rooms with their Japanese screens and Japanese soaking tubs with views high above Tokyo. But it was the staff who confirmed to us that Aman can bring their magic to city tower blocks, as for example they accompanied us downstairs to ensure we chose gifts appropriate for the Japanese friends we were dining with that night. We had to leave early next morning for our flight, but not until we had enjoyed through room service - at 5:30 am - the best breakfast (think continental meets kaiseki) I have ever tasted. Aman Tokyo, like the Park Hyatt, deserves to be a movie location.

Tokyo Aman is indeed an amazing Hotel. Perfectly located, with a subway station under the building. Amazing rooms and beautiful lobby and restaurant/bar area. Highly Recommend!! The views from the restaurant and our room were superb. Staff were so helpful and accomadating.

I am an avid Amanjunkie and have travelled extensively in Japan (I also used to live there for many years). During my travels for both pleasure and business i stayed in the best hotels and ryokans around the country and truly nothing comes close to the Aman in Tokyo: it is like an urban oasis in the middle of a bustling city, a combination of the best ryokan with the all the amenities of a contemporary hotel. When you enter into the lobby you are in awe of the height and the sense of space which is so rare in Japan. You are basically in a cocoon up in the sky and the rooms are all in the 4 floors above the lobby. The views are sensational, the ever changing ikebana center piece of the lobby mesmerizing, the attention to detail typical Aman. We stayed in a suite which was more like an apartment, with a seperate living room, kitchenette, office and toilette and it was the perfect room to be able to entertain and have a private dinner with friends / business associates. The actual bedroom (which i understand is the standard room) is so spacious and so comfortable with ample living and closet space, and a lovely bathroom which included a shower and a traditional Japanese ofuro. The Spa and the gym are sublime and the swimming pool up in the sky is like no other (albeit the water is a bit too warm if you want to swim laps). Loved the Japanese traditional baths in the changing rooms as well as all the little amenities. My only complaint was that there was no in house shiatsu therapist and during the 4 days i was there it was not possible to schedule a shiatsu with the visiting therapist. Overall it was an unfortgettable experience and if i have to find a flaw, that would the slow service in the dinning areas (during all times).Hospitality in Tokyo is now on a completely different level, and i dare say, that although the hotel is pricy, it is really worth the price you pay. Wether for business or pleasure, the Aman Tokyo is by far the best place to stay in town. Special thanks need to go out to Mrs Seiko-san, the lovely kimono clad Japanese lady from Kyoto who attended to our every need and made our stay most memorable. Domo Arigato. Cant wait to go back

Loved this hotel. Incredible rooms with great deep tubs to soak while admiring Tokyo from the 36th floor. Modern yet definitely Japanese, with very comfortable beds and large rooms. The restaurant for breakfast was very good and I love the fact they have a well appointed cigar lounge. Great service and easy access to the underground system and close to Tokyo station. Even Though it is in the financial district its minutes to imperial park and palace. Will stay again for sure

BEAUTIFUL IN EVERY WAY!!!We got lucky and found that Aman was opening a property in Tokyo right when my girlfriend and I were going to be there. We love Aman and booked our 4 night stay.Unfortunately there weren't many taxi drivers that knew where it was at the time (I'm sure it is different now compared to April of last year) but when we walked inside, we were completely impressed by the level of service AND the overwhelming feeling you get when you enter the sky lobby area. We were speechless, it felt completely zen-like with huge ceilings. Beautiful!!Our room was awesome. It was huge!!! You will not find rooms like this anywhere else in the world. The views are as beautiful as the furnishings and setup of the room and bathroom.The service is unbeatable and matches that of any of the other Aman properties we've stayed at. The best!The location of the hotel - you are in Otemachi district of Chiyoda so of course you are near the tourist and business buzz but everything is easily accessible via their connected subway. I've stayed at every modern major 5 star property in the city and Aman easily is the best overall hotel with their style, service, and comfort. Highly recommend!!

review_body: The Aman Tokyo has the best rooms in the city. At around 760 sq ft, they are large by an measure. The layout is perfect, with plenty of closet space for two people, and the views (particularly of the Imperial Palace Gardens) are stunning. I agree with some reviews that there are a few service areas that could be improved. But anything amiss was rapidly remedied after a mere mention of a concern. The housekeeping and spa/fitness staff were incredible! The concierge team was up to any challenge. The hotel has.....by far....the best pool, fitness and spa facility in all of Tokyo. It was an absolute pleasure to work out and alternately relax in so much space with such beautiful views. Overall, I do think this is the best hotel in Tokyo (having stayed at Four Seasons Marunouchi, Mandarin Oriental, Peninsula, and Hyatt properties in the past). When we booked the hotel was sold out and only the 'lowest' category room (Deluxe) was available. In the end the room was superb and I probably wouldn't ever pay the 25% premium for the next category room (The Premier Room which is identical except for a larger bathroom). Also many of the suites do not have Imperial Palace views, which I far prefer to city/distant Tokyo Bay views.

Everything was big in this hotel, starting from the very high ceiling lobby until the rooms.Got the biggest suite and it was huge! Huge living room, huge bedroom, huge bathroom. It was a corner suite so we were surrounded by floor-to-ceiling windows. Every night when we came back to the room, there would be something personal waiting for us even if it was only a few mochis or fruits. The staffs were really helpful and really fluent in English.Try the cocktail and sake in the bar, you won't regret it. But don't expect a noisy bar where you can laugh out loud.

If you are familiar with Aman, this does not disappoint. It has all the luxuries one expects of a top end hotel. The rooms are big, toiletries spa-like and the service is excellent. The mini bar is complimentary (except for alcoholic drinks and juices) and there is Japanese snacks in the room. The view is of course very good as the rooms are between 36-38 floors I think.The hotel is above a metro station - Otemachi station, and is connected with 5 lines. It is about 5-10min walk from Tokyo station. Like many high end hotels now, Aman does ala carte breakfast, but somehow I still prefer a buffet spread where I get to choose my food from a wide spread for breakfast (which is not done here).

I travel to Tokyo many times a year for business and stayed in different 5-6 stars hotel. Shangri-la, Ritz, Peninsula, MO etc etc and is my first time in Aman Tokyo. I was having a high expectation as the price for the room here is almost 50% higher than other big names in Tokyo. I was expecting Aman will "WOW" me. But unfortunately, apart from the deco of the room. I just can't find any other thing in this hotel that will make me visit it the second time. The room is very nice, extremely large with excellent view! Japanese Zen deco with very high ceiling and big windows. Bathroom is also nice with a very nice bathtub!The Lobby is nice but very "office lobby" look a like. Food in Restaurant is very very average (i suggest you to eat else where!) Service is very average (you got excellent service in Japan everywhere!). And if this is name the "Aman" service, then I will be very disappointed.I really don't think it worth the price to stay here as I think I need a more "all round" experience for a comfortable stay!

This hotel continues to reinforce the Aman brand's pledge to brilliance. Aman Tokyo opened March 2015. We stayed three nights In December 2015 and were wowed constantly. From the dramatic lobby with city/Mt. Fuji views to gorgeous rooms with same dramatic views to the spectacular pool, this hotel does not disappoint. Service was very good. Some language barriers but overall, Aman quality. I highly recommend this if visiting Tokyo. Also, very convenient to main Tokyo train station and central business district.

In the last 10 years, there are many new addition to high end hotels. Among them, Aman Tokyo definitely definitely offers one of the best, if not the best experience for those who want to stay with a style. In the first place, the building is amazing. You might have a little difficulties identifying its entrance at the ground level. But once you go to the lobby at 33rd floor, you find gorgeous lobby with breathtaking views. Rooms are designed with a good integration of Japanese and western style. I must say that it is improvised style with more emphasis on comtemporary which offers maximum funcionality and not at all the same as Ryokan, which offers more traditional Japanese atmosphere. But if you are not Japanese, you would find this a good balance. Staffs are very friendly and well trained. They care each guest very much and quite attentive. Sports gym is nice. But you really need to check indoor pool, sauna and large bath. Those facilities are by itself offers the reason to stay this hotel. Breakfast is very nice. It is flavorful and very healthy. It is not a buffet style but the portion is just right and you would be satisfied. However, they have only one restaurant for a dinner and the quality is just OK though view is nice. Actually Tokyo has so many good restaurant (has more Michellin 3-star restaurants than any other cities including Paris) that it is tough for the hotel dining to stand up. Overall, for those who sees value in upscale facilities, attentive service, gorgeous views and so on, I highly recommend Aman Tokyo I wouldn't stay here while I am in Tokyo for a business trip and go back to hotel only to sleep. But if I visit Tokyo for vacation and don't mind staying more time at the hotel. this is one of my favorite.

Stunning rooms, very large by big city standards, with a very large bathroom with Japanese bath. Immaculate service and attention to detail. Great laundry service. The hostess in her traditional dress spoke perfect English and was most helpful as was the concierge. A wonderful guide was arranged for us who took us on 2 half day tours of Tokyo by train taxi and walking. an experience well worth while as you glean a lot of information and stop at out of the way coffee houses and see some great architectural pieces. The hotel sits above a train station which makes it all easy. We also walked to the Ginza and the Imperial gardens are nearby. There is a beautiful spa and I thoroughly enjoyed my massage but it was not cheap. I would not agree with another reviewer as to service. We got the usual friendly and efficient Aman 6 star service.As a result of this being the newest hotel in Tokyo it is very popular with groups of local women coming for high tea and when we had friends for drinks before dinner at 6pm it was hard to get a table near the bar as the customers did not want to move.As this is a city hotel we paid for all meals but did enjoy 2 dinners in the restaurant. good waiters and a knowledgable sommelier. There are good French patisseries in walking distance if you want a simple cheaper breakfast

My family and I shared a 3 nights stay in Nov in their standard room as shown in the photos. Having stayed at other Aman locations in Asia and Europe, we had high expectation of the premise. The interior/decor is impeccable, subtle but a low key luxurious modern Japanese style. However, we all found the services are abit rusty, considering the cost and usual Aman standard. Upon arrival (arrived at 2.40pm) they insisted on sitting us at the lobby until 3pm as it is the official check in time. At 3.10pm the room is ready, I was being guided to my room, however it was only until 20mins my luggages arrived. For my usual 5-stars hotel experiences, the luggages are often in room already prior entering, not to mention we had to wait for 30mins at the lobby for the room to be ready. The rest of stay we have received regular greeting letter and welcoming snacks in room from the hotel. But they seemed to be given out of formality. One morning we approached the concierge desk to ask if we would need a reservation for breakfast for a group of 6 as some local friends will be joining us in the morning after. She said yes, however instead of helping us making the reservation on the spot, she had made us to walk all the way to the breakfast restaurant to make the booking ourselves where it could be just one phone call away for her)During one meal spent in the hotel, we kindly asked the hotel to prepare a slice of a cake as our friend happened to be spending her birthday in Tokyo. We were refused at first, claiming that they do not have any cake they can offer. We went back and asked about the cake options on the in room dining menu, we also expressed that we are happy to cover all costs, and at last we got our cake.If all the above happened in a 4 star or a generic 5 star hotel, we probably wouldn't feel as disappointed. Also, in Japan where they usually have the most superb retail and hospitality services, and not to mention having paid more than 1000usd one night, we expect the usual "Aman standard" where they would take an extra effort to make sure a pleasant stay for their guests.Comparing other options, I would probably recommend Peninsula or Grand Hyatt for a comfortable stay in Tokyo.

My wife and I stayed at The Aman Tokyo the first two nights in Tokyo. With this trip being the start of our honeymoon, the staff did everything they could to make it incredible. They arranged tough to squi reservations at Narisawa and Kawamura, scheduled a private sake tasting on property, and also arranged private guides for tours.The hotel lobby and rooms are particularly impressive. We have stayed at some of the top hotels across the world and the Aman Tokyo has the wow factor.

Let me say this clearly...this is one stunning hotel...Location excellent, architecture, public rooms and suites/rooms marvelous...Don't be deterred by people talking about austere atmosphere...you feel at home right away...the spa and swimming pool are a gem..The downside...the service..front door, reception and room service excellent.Restaurant service notably at breakfast a very choppy ride worth 3***, slow, inattentive and disorganized...a far cry from Mandarin Oriental and Peninsula...major teething problems here, due to lack of supervision and clear work assignment. You arrive at the restaurant ...nobody to greet you...a five minutes wait...you know what you are in for...The Bar is stunning...the cheesy pop music from a tape on continuous rotation is graceless...All this can and must be changed...and the...perfection...

The room is very big when compare to all other hotels in Tokyo. Very nice and relax decor. Nice bathroom size and have a Japanese bath tub looking out a nice view. We went to their swimming pool and was very nice and decent size.

My wife and I are still recovering from a 5 night stay at the Aman Tokyo in November 2015 after being home for over a week. From the moment we arrived at the hotel service was delivered with grace and aplomb. This was our 2nd stay at an Aman property so we had reasonable expectations. At Aman, you don't sign bills in the restaurants as the hosts are expected to know your name and anticipate your needs. For example, a doorman greeted us by name upon exiting our taxi the 2nd night of our stay!We stayed in a deluxe king room on the 38th (top) floor. The spacious room had a king bed, chaise and closet big enough for two pro level shoppers. Our bathroom featured double sinks, an enclosed WC and expansive shower + tub area with a view that rivaled the main room. There were a couple of minor snafus with service in the restaurant, one time the server forgot our order and we waited over 20 mins for attention. Aman has a large gym and spa with an indoor swimming pool on the 35th floor; we received very good massages in the spa and utilized much of the gym equipment. My only complaint is the gym temperature was cold but there was NO AIRFLOW. Overall service and the room exceeded our expectations. We travel a lot and look forward to returning.

We loved loved loved the Aman! Such a beautiful hotel, from the lobby with its soaring ceilings and excellent views (all the way to Mount Fuji on a clear day) to the rooms which are huge and calming with their zen-like furnishings. The swimming pool is also beautiful and wonderful to swim in.Location wise it's very convenient being just above the Otemachi station which has many connections to key locations in Tokyo. The hotel is in the business district and is surrounded by many offices and banks so not much in terms of nightlife around it. However, the walk to Ginza from the hotel (if you don't fancy taking the train) is fairly easy. About 15 minutes. Service is very good too with typical Japanese graciousness. Everyone speaks excellent English. I can't wait to go back. If only it wasn't so expensive!

We had visited the Aman resorts before, but this was our first time to visit them in a city. The atmosphere was very calming after leaving the chaotic streets of Tokyo. They really brought in the resort atmosphere. The views extended every where, we especially like the pool. Our trip was quick, but we will go back in a second.

This hotel has a stunning dark, sparse, minimalist yet giant lobby and the suite rooms have an unbelievable view of the expansive Tokyo. The rooms where very spacious, light and open and incredibly relaxing after long days of touring with so many people in the City. The view at night from the bar is off the chain and I can't imagine a better view. We did not eat at the new Italian restaurant at the bottom level of the hotel but wish we did because the line on Sunday was 4 blocks long of people trying to get in. The staff was very attentive but not very knowledgeable of the the restaurants. The breakfast was so wonderful and very Western when you really need to take a break from the Japanese food. They did a great job with a few accents in the room to show appreciation of their guests such as bath salts specialized for Japan and Aman. This was definitely worth the splurge! Thank you for making our trip very memorable.

Stayed at Aman Tokyo in Sep 2015 for four nights with wife and 9-month old daughter in an Aman Suite. Despite being in a business area, we found the hotel conveniently located for tourists. Our suite was on the corner of the building with beautiful views out over Akihabara to the north and the Imperial Gardens/Shinjuku to the West--the highlight was watching the sun rise and Mt. Fuji come into view behind the buildings. As always, Aman's decor (minimalist south Asian style) was elegant, though the Tokyo hotel was more "Ikea-ish" than other Aman's at which we've stayed.The food was generally good (breakfast every day plus one late night dinner in the restaurant), but nothing was particularly memorable and service was generally impersonal in the restaurant. The highlight there, however, was Japanese whiskey at the lobby bar. Their bartenders were expert, engaging, and interesting people, and we spent ~90 min learning about the whiskeys and talking to the bartenders.In terms of service, there was one big, humongous, unable-to-ignore miss: the hotel knew we had a 9-month old well in advance (60-days-plus; I'd spoken with the concierge) of our visit, but failed to reserve a crib, and one was not available for our stay. One staff member apologized, but did nothing to 'recover' from the mistake. That one miss stained the whole experience, as it meant our daughter slept on the floor for four days.

Was expecting great things from The Aman...but after staying at the Park Hyatt Tokyo for the immediate 2 preceeding days before checking into The Aman, you can really sense the shortfall in service. The staff have obviously all read the Manual but the effort to anticipate your comfort is stifled and jumpy (which actually makes you tense up if you do not like deferential 'you are my master' service). At the other extreme, you have staff who act "Uber Sophisticated" and that just narks you off. For what you pay, it falls below expecrtations....I personally prefer the Park Hyatt.

We had a six night stay here in October 2015 (room 110). This hotel in the Chiyoda district opened in December 2014 in a tower block that overlooks the Imperial Palace; the moat of the palace is a five minute walk from the hotel. The immediate area around the hotel is populated mainly by offices, though the hotel has a smart cafe at the ground floor next to the entrance, and the building is not far from the Ginza (about a mile). Just to the side of the hotel, down an escalator, is a mini shopping mall. This has a few restaurants and cafes, a convenience store, pharmacist and a florist, which may come in useful during your stay. It also has access to the Otemachi metro station. If you are coming from the airport then the hotel is a very short taxi ride, or indeed a walk, from Tokyo station. The ground floor reception has a bank of lifts that whisk you to the 33rd floor to a vast, airy lobby with a massive picture window looking out over the city; on a clear day you can see Mount Fuji in the distance.The rooms are huge by Tokyo standards, without clutter (the TV is tucked discreetly away in a wooden cabinet at the foot of the bed and emerges from its home on request via a bank of high tech controls at the bedside. There are chairs, table and chaise longue by the picture window, and a tastefully lit single plant pot on display to one side. The bathroom is generously sized, with excellent shower and a computerised toilet of the kind that the Japanese love; this one lifts its lid as you approach, and flushes automatically. It could probably beat you at Scrabble if it put its mind to it. The Internet in the room is ultra fast, with download speed of 85 MBps and upload speed only a touch less, which to put into context is over six times faster than current European average broadband speed. One feature that I like but so rarely encounter is the provision of ample electrical sockets at easily reachable height, a bank of them via a discrete wooden panel at the head of the bed. There are large closets with sliding shoji doors. This is one of the best designed hotel rooms that I have stayed in anywhere. My only caveat is that, for those with delicate backs, the mattress is at the firm end of the softness spectrum. The hotel has a spectacular swimming pool and well equipped spa/fitness facility accessible from the the 34th floor, with the restaurant at the lobby level looking out over the panoramic view over the city. Staff are attentive, helpful and plentiful. There are lots of little touches that elude most luxury hotels. If you plug some electrical device in then when you next check back into your room you will find the cable neatly tied. The laundry is returned in a box so elegantly wrapped that it looks like a birthday gift. The concierge staff are helpful and diligent, and the staff on the door greeted me by name from the second day onwards, The Aman is a spectacular modern hotel and a well located haven to stay in this vibrant city.

Great hotel, fabulous staff and very nice spa! We only ate breakfast at the hotel, but it was fantastic!The hotel is in the business district so the area is quiet, but very nice and close proximity to great restaurants and shopping.

Firstly it needs to be said that expectations of Aman guests are that they will get the whole Aman experience at each of their properties. That is what you buy into. Tricky here, because this is a big city hotel. To replicate that fine Aman experience outside of the Aman resort scenario is not easy. Aman Tokyo succeeds - mostly. It is an absolutely breathtaking hotel. The Lobby is utterly gorgeous. The restaurant beautiful (more about that later), and the Spa a knockout (more later).Check in was swift and exemplary. My suite, a Deluxe King, was very spacious and beautifully appointed, in a classic, Japanese style. Incredibly comfortable bed and an amazing bathroom with heated stone floors and a gorgeous stone tub at the window for traditional Japanese bathing. It was a daily ritual for me and unbelievably relaxing. The Spa with it's pre-treatment bathing areas and steam room was wonderful. The body scrub, massage and facial I had were all top-notch. The heated indoor pool is the best and most dramatic in Tokyo.Service in the hotel was excellent throughout my stay. It was a little disconcerting at times though to be asked my room number on so many occasions. This is where the Aman touch was put to the test. Being a larger property for them I have no doubt it's not easy to remember every guest by name, but it is what is expected of an Aman property.I had great conversations with the GM and F&B Manager whose level of expertise and service really shone through. Here is where I felt the true Aman hospitality.The food in the restaurant was excellent. I had a delicious dinner - a very innovative and well constructed menu. Breakfast was fantastic - you could tell the quality of the ingredients. Really very good.I was a little disappointed not to receive a room upgrade, both through my Amex FHR benefits and also considering I have stayed at so many Aman properties. This was the first time I have not been upgraded at an Aman. It doesn't sit that well with me. I know the next category room was available as I checked. Duly noted for future reservations.Check out was a little cold - another area where it was let down. Checking and paying the bill in a crowded lobby while a junior member of staff hovered over me was a little unpleasant. No wave off here by the senior staff or personal goodbye from the GM. This also differentiated this property from Amanresorts.Small quips though - I loved my stay here. It is still young and I have no doubt there will be further improvement. It just didn't have that "over and above" Aman sheen. The little extra touches were missing. It's probably close to the very best hotel in Tokyo right now. I would think it will definitely be at the top of that tree soon.

My husband and I love the Aman group. This is the 6th property of theirs that we have stayed at. Aman properties are synonymous with personalized service, a sense of exclusivity, exceeding expectations and a customized experience. The reason we chose Aman over other 5 star hotels is because we were looking not just for a luxurious experience but for the AMAN experience. It has been the standard that at all the other Amans we have been to, we were greeted and constantly addressed by our name. Staff went over and beyond to make sure we felt special (arranging popcorn on the beach, upgrades to beach villas, champagne on arrival). Like Ninjas, you don’t feel that they are there but they show up, anticipating your needs even before you open your mouth. They are eager to make sure your needs are attended to and are having a wonderful stay. We also look forward to the small exclusive touches like bag tags with our names on them, token Aman gifts (that represent that specific country –examples : a painted frog in Amandari, a capiz looking turtle in Amanpulo etc) on the bed right after turn down service and doing all possible instead if saying “no” or “we can’t.” When we got to this hotel we were welcomed like any other five star hotel (but not the AMAN way). This was a special occasion so we were hoping for an upgrade (our reservation said complimentary upgrade when available) but of course no upgrade. The letter of welcome in the room said “Dear guest”. In all the other AMANs they usually have our names on the welcome letter. When we had drinks at the bar with a friend in the evening, we experienced neglected service. We were sitting on the couch away from the bar and it was pretty much empty and it was so difficult to flag a waiter down to order and reorder drinks. When a waiter did take our order not only was he not friendly at all but it seemed as if we bothered him. Once a guest feels like they are bothering a waitstaff – that is not good. For breakfast we advised the waitstaff that we were rushing to bring out the food all together as soon as possible – sadly the kitchen lost our order so we missed the main breakfast. However, there were several AMAN worthy staff that made us realise that the hotel has AMAN potential. Kumiko the concierge was very warm, personable, always called us by our names and truly took care of our requests and reservations. Flordian who did the simple kind act of insisting and bringing my coffee for me from the dining room to the library and refuse to allow me to carry it myself (very kind and impressive). It was raining pretty strong so we had to walk underground to get to our dinner destination and Daichi went beyond the call of duty to help us find our way as it was pretty complicated. He did not leave us (even if we kept on telling him we were fine – super service) until he was confident that we would not get lost. When I was paying the bill, Yusuke (I hope this is the correct spelling of his name and I am guessing he is a senior manager) came over and apologised for the delay in the breakfast we had earlier in the morning (we did not end up eating the main dish because it took too long and we were in a rush). He said that there was no excuse for that and so he offered to comp our evening drinks. He gave me an Aman umbrella as a souvenir (which I originally wanted to purchase). We were on our way out and he had the hotel car take my husband and I to the train station because he could see we were rushing and pressed for time. Those gestures saved the experience for us. All the staff who took care of us from him onward started to call us by our names and finally we felt the Aman touch during the last few hours of our stay.We loved the location as it was centrally located and had 3 major subway lines right under the building. It is walking distance to Tokyo Station so very convenient if you are coming in on the Narita Express train. The room was spacious, modern and had a wonderful huge sofa by the window which is the part we liked most. We would have preferred the city view as the palace view had so many construction cranes breaking the view. We also appreciated the heated floors in the bathroom as well as the Ofuro tub. The room colors reminded us of Amankora. The breakfast at the restaurant was actually very good. The ingredients they used were fresh and well chosen. The fresh juices and pastries were also noteworthy. If only they can speed up the service as it takes too long in between courses. The hotel has only been open a couple of months so I am hoping that even if they are a city Aman they can still go back to being the Aman that we know in a non city setting. Go back to the heart of Aman – know your guests and make them feel at home. I know they can get there if they just go back to the true spirit of what makes an Aman property what it is.

It is our first time staying in Aman resort. It was famed as urban resort and it is.We reserved on its official website and the process was smooth. Few days before our arrival, we received email confirming the reservation and offered concierge service and transport advice. We started our vacation….Arrival was a bit of problem. We took Narita Express to Tokyo station and got on a taxi. The driver has not heard of Aman Hotel, not even the exact address that we provided. Google map and calling to the hotel could not help also. We went around the Otemachi area for 10 minutes without reaching the hotel lobby.The frustration was totally wiped away when we reached the hotel lobby on 33/F. It was just gorgeous. We have stayed in many upscale hotels in Tokyo but this one was just WOW. The lobby was spacious and zen, in Japanese style. Check-in process was a breeze and we were shown to our room and the bell staff was waiting for us with our luggage in front of our room. The front desk staff explained switches and services patiently.The suite was spacious, beautifully decorated and well appointed. It was about the biggest room we had stayed in Tokyo. Much of the nice things about the room was said by other contributors and I am not going to repeat.There is one restaurant on lobby level serving breakfast, lunch and dinner. We decided to try dinner there. When we arrived, we had to wait for a while. It was because a table by the window became available just before we arrived and the staff thoughtfully moved us to the window table. Overall food quality was good. They used fresh ingredients from around the country. The chef took effort to create delicious dishes. Service staff was well mannered but they were not experienced. I am sure given more training, it would be a good restaurant.We had breakfast there too. Again, food quality was excellent and service was so so. Can you imagine the staff clear the plates and scrape the left-over food from one plate to the other in front of the guest before bringing the plates away?I see that the staff were polite and passionate. They just need more training and experience to make the hotel to full 5 star.After all the praises to this hotel, I would like to recommend the hotel to improve in environment consciousness. The normal shower gel/shampoo/conditioner in other hotels are around 30 - 40 ml each. Aman's is 150 ml each. If the guest stays for 1 night and he is not bringing the bottles home to use, quite a lot was wasted.

アマンリゾートが日本初進出とのことで泊まってきました。他のアマンホテルには泊まったことはありません。広々としたロビーで和を意識した落ち着いた空間です。そして時間が止まったかのような、とても静かでした。部屋も和を意識しつつも広々として機能的で良かったです。お風呂がとても良かった。スイーツも置いてあって嬉しかった。プールも行きましたが、誰も泳いでなくて伸び伸びと泳げました。レストランにも行きました。量は少な目でしたがワインがおいしかった。唯一残念だったのは、会計の時に違う人のを持ってこられて、頼んでないものまで入ってたのでびっくりしてしまいました。それ以外は特に不満はありませんでした。It's the first time for me to stay Hotel Aman resorts.The lobby was wide, open space, calm and there were many bamboo grasses, I thought it's nice.The room was large, comfortable and especially I was impressed by the bathroom. When I went to pool, no one was there.I was so relaxed. Unfortunately, there was the mistake that my bill was other one's.

OK, as an Amanjunkie, this place does not really qualify as an Aman for us. Normally an Aman has 30 + rooms (suites / villas), and Aman Tokyo has 84-86 rooms.That said, it is a big jump better than the normal fare of the Four Seasons, Peninsula hotels etc.The rooms are huge, and the main foyer is incredible. The views over the Imperial Palace are superb, as are views in other directions over Tokyo.We ate out at night, but breakfast and snacks were very good. The bar is also great.Annoyingly, and unlike most other Aman properties, the public spaces were just that, filled by the public. This certainly detracts from the Aman (this is your home...) philosophy, but it is still the pick for somewhere to stay in Tokyo.The pool is incredible...and Aman masterpiece.

My partner Ken and I just came back from an eight night stay at the AMAN. This is hands down the best hotel in Tokyo right now and we have stayed at them all.Stepping off the whisper quiet elevator into the lobby you're faced with the welcoming faces of the staff who live to make sure you are having an amazing time while you stay.Check-in is a smooth comfortable experience which takes place in the lobby along with your hot towel and welcome drink. The lobby is spectacular. Soaring ceilings of paper and walls of stone anchored by a large reflecting pool.The bar and lounge area as well as the fine dining restaurant are all located within and butt up against windows supplying amazing views of The Imperial Gardens and Tokyo.A tour of the facility is offered, though we chose to go right to the room.THE ROOM!...and what a room it is. The first part of our eight days (we checked out for Kyoto and back in for another four) we had a suite, which can only be described as Heaven. Sparse, well designed and brimming with the WOW factor I so appreciate. A touch of a button (bedside) releases two sets of electric shades which revel HUGE, huge windows overlooking the city. A very comfortable day bed sits underneath. A reading lamp and round table and chairs complemented this area. Next to this and working towards the opposite end of the room is the console which houses your TV, fridge, coffee ect. The TV is hidden within and raises from view at the touch of a remote button.Following is the bed area. The bed itself is a massive size and provides plenty of individual sleeping space. Each side of the bed includes a panel of buttons that control lighting for the room as well as temperature and house keeping calls.Ample closets space are seperated with a drawer system between. The closet also includes a safe and a basket for laundry and/or dry cleaning. We used both and were very satisfied. The bathroom is a large area including double stone sinks and depending on your room size a large or VERY large stone tub. This area also has an open rain shower. Floors are heated stone.The toilet is behind a sliding door and of course has a high end model TOTO. The suite included a large entrance area with door and the room was larger with a much larger bath area. Both this room and standard which he had the second check-in are beautiful.You will NOT be unhappy.THE POOL is so over the top its insane. I keep using the word HUGE, but it's HUGE. The surrounding deck area is equipped with large "beds" to relax on. There is a lifeguard and water bottles ect are available. The temperature is just right.THE GYM is not huge but is bigger than others and has every piece of equipment you could want for your workout. There are also Pilates and Yoga studios if you so need. We did not use the SPA areas but they looked great.FOOD. The main restaurant is located just off the lobby. Again large, large windows provide ample views.The food is very good. Breakfast everyday was yummy.There are "set" menus for both American and Japanese breakfasts as well as a la cart choices.The staff is so capable and loving.There is also a small second restaurant located off the hotel entrance outside.I really want to take the time to address other reviews of this hotel...The hotel is anything but Goth. If you even have a slight idea of what Goth represents it's not the AMAN.The design is Japanese. High end, MODERN, sparse, very placed. It is not about rugs and upholstered chairs or gold leaf accents. If that's what you're looking for than you can look elsewhere.To be disappointed in the design of a hotel or room which is clearly visible in every photo online prior to your trip is just bad planning on the travelers part.The toilet area of the room has a door which is also behind a sliding shoji screen wall.The staff ALL speak English. I had no problem communicating with anyone. My concierge emails were returned in clear and conscience writing concerning many lunch and dinner reservations.The general manager, Jeffrey Seward introduced himself to us and was very welcoming and helpful.Obviously we loved our stay here. On two separate occasions we brought Japanese friends who live in Tokyo to view the hotel. All were blown away. One is a very famous cosmetics mogul and can be the pickiest of the pickiest. She actually is booking a room for herself she was so impressed.One thing to note. If you are taking the N'EX from the airport and walk over it can be hard to find the entrance The main entrance where you depart your bus, car, cab is on the opposite side from where you would walk in coming from that direction.Go stay here. You will love it.

review_body: The Aman group has been reinventing hotels and resorts for a long time. They have a reputation for excellence and stays beyond perfection. Aman Tokyo has a long way to go before their soft product catches up with the stunning lobby and public spaces. English is a big problem here and it shouldn't be. The hotel generic email person doesn't type very well and couldn't tell me the predicted dates for the Cherry Blossom season. Waiters should understand English and not need to be told twice or three times in slow halting English. We're in an Aman here.The food produce is stellar. They use the best of the best ingredients and you get what you pay for. The rooms are spartan or what they call sophisticated Zen. They're really quite bare for what you're paying. Some of the furniture looks like it came from Misato IKEA. None of the oriental opulence found at the Mandarin Oriental or Shangri-la. I wish they had a door separating the bathroom from the bedroom because without it, you do end up hearing everything from the bathroom. The bathtub is a wonder though. Very deep and with a flowing spout.There's none of the name recognition and no bills signature necessary that is common at their warm weather resorts either. I just felt like a cog staying at yet another generic, albeit luxurious hotel in Tokyo.

If you want to try the top in tokyo please go to aman tokyo It s really impressive the service, the way they do the ckeck in, the presence of the manager all the time, the room (wowwwwww) It s a wonderful room large space view of the emperor garden just six floor of a high building in tokyo this hotel is a dream and you don t want to Wake up It s a really all modern japanese hotelAll japan is inside in a modern wayI loved this hotel Just a very little problem Food is not at the same level than the high quality of the hotelTaste and plates need a new check Don t miss the pool. Absolutely wonderful I really want to know another aman in another country if it s so wonderful than tokyo

The light filled enormity of the 32 nd floor reception room is so amazing ( you have to see it to experience it the photos cannot reflect and feels so Japanese, loved the location , the sleep quality was fantastic , the pool area is brilliant 30 meters + and what a view!! . I loved the yomana exercise classes the hotel puts on , really worth trying the staff ae just amazing and concierge team fantastic, can't wait to return

This is truly a great hotel. We moved here from Peninsula and what a difference! The rooms are large, the views are great and, most importantly, they exude a modern zen "warmth". The service is exceptional.In terms of location, it is a little further away from the touristy hubs of Ginza, Shibuya, Omotesando and Shinjuku compared to the Ginza hotels such as Peninsula. However, the Otemachi metro station is just below the hotel and has good connections via the Marunouchi, Chiyoda, Hanzomon, Tozai and the Toei Mita lines. It is also a short walk away to Tokyo JR station.

You've seen photos of the lobby in travel magazines and on the Aman web-site but that won't prepare you for the wow-feeling when you finnaly arrive at the 33rd floor. The airy, spacious and absolutely stunning inner-roof and the overall serene feeling of the lobby despite the vastness of it all. Aman has arrived in Tokyo. Big time. And as a guest you really feel "I have arrived!".The room is probably the best/coolest designed hotel room we have ever stayed in. The lay-out of the room is similar to Amansara which is natural as Kerry Hill designed both. Light woods apart from the black stone bathroom and the black bathtub (almost like a plunge pool) from where you can enjoy the fabulous urban vista. And the hotel may be my overall winner in terms of design and looks. The halls, the pool, the spa - everything looks amazing.The service is very friendly and efficient but I would say that Peninsula in Tokyo still has the upper edge in terms of service. Aman Tokyo is only 6 months old though.Breakfast was very good but not fantastic. I would have preferred more to choose from. Views are great from all sides of the building. I'm not sure which view I would choose from my room. Maybe west side towards Imperial Palace and Shinjuku skyline in the distance is cooler but the bar and restaurant have that side so maybe you should go for a room on the other side - then you get a Tokyo view from most angles (the pool is to the South)All in all - one of the best hotel stays of all time for us. Once you check in you never want to check out. Ever

For those that think the hotel is overly gothic, they are right… its on a parallel with the artistry of a Gothic cathedral like Chartres or Notre Dame. Ok, maybe that’s a little extreme but the design is exceptional. The soaring ceiling of the lobby mixed with the quite of the bar and the hospitality of the reception makes your arrival both awe inspiring and personal; a combination rarely achieved. Pool is a stand out with glass windows that seem to go on forever and views 35 stories up over the imperial palace; swimming is a great way to get over jet lag btw. Rooms are large and the sunken granite tub in the bathroom was truly special. Breakfast was amazing, especially the Japanese breakfast. Been to many top Ryokan’s would say breakfast was on par (though maybe not as good as some). Anyway, I think most travelers staying at this small hotels are too hip to write tripadvisor reviews so I think its getting a bit unfairly treated and I wanted to have my say. Better than Four Seasons, Peninsula or Shangri La. Thanks for reading.

A relatively new hotel. The entrance was quite hard to locate. Taxi drivers don't really know where the hotel is. Reception and lobby area is stunning with high ceilings and the full windows cast plenty of natural light into the waiting area. The hotel was fully booked at that time but it didn't looked or feel crowded. Rooms and bathroom are exceptionally huge by Tokyo standards. The pool is heated with heated floors too! Very close to Tokyo station!

Aman manages to understand and express what Japan is in a way, in my opinion, no other international group of hotels has managed to do in Tokyo so far. First of it is peaceful liked ryokan, it reminds me of Gora Kadan in peacefulness and exclusivity. The rooms are beautiful and very Japanese, I love the kimono option provided, the Japanese bath, the attention to details, not to mentioned the breakfast is so beautifully as well this presented in a seating arrangement in front of a full hight window with views of the city and so good it is clearly the best we have had in Tokyo and likely the best we have had in Japan. Also the pool is a complete retreat, the gym is small but state of the art both with great view, th lobby bar and lounge is peaceful, beautiful and very private. We where a little bit astounded By the restaurant, it would have been completely perfect with it to be fairly traditional Japanese so some sort of Mediterranean Japanese seemed such a strange presentation for a hotel that otherwise has refined what Japan is all about down to an art.To other reviewers and future guests I would say if you like to have a peaceful and private retreat from the madness of Tokyo you are going to love Aman however if you prefer happening and buzzling go elsewhere.The only setbacks I have are the fact that despite making no bookings with benefits of late check out and such, these benefits where extremely hard forr Aman to accommodate which was quit irritating taking into account we checked in at midnight!Also we at first felt concierge could have been a little more experienced, we used to have a hotel concierge in Tokyo with magic abilities however we ended up being extremely happy with that part of the hotel to. As we are a little tired of the whole Michelin star craze, been there done that and feel that in a city like Tokyo with so much great sushi it is a bit of a joke about the hype of certain places. There was just one restaurant we would have loved to try and when that was not possible asked to get some good no reservation required places for wagyu, sushi and izakaya and in regards to sushi the concierge was spot on with her recommendations, we could not have been happier and close to the hotel as well. Perhaps a little out of the way from Ebisu, Daikanyama, Nakameguro as well as Omotesando but close enough to Ginza. The fact that the metro is in the basement is great and ther are also som e restaurants there too. Very close to Tokyo Station for Kyoto and Hakone etc.

Let's start by first saying the staff could not be more friendlier and helpful. They are at your every need from the moment you walk in to the second you leave. The hotel itself is stunning but it's a little bit out of the way and super quite. This has been my second trip back to Japan and to be honest I found the Peninsula just as nice with a much better location. The other thing that truly disappointed me was trying to get a massage. In the few days I was there they where always full all day long. Never had a high end hotel not be able to some how accommodate a massage. While I give this a high rating ,based on the location and quietness of the lobby area I won't be running back to that location but love the Aman properties worldwide

It was a challenge finding the cryptic entrance with the only help my iphone. But this is part of the AMAN experience, exclusivity, or in this case more exclusivity than other places, but less than the aman resorts. I need to disclose that I love the AMAN resorts. So, an AMAN hotel was an experiment that I wanted to be part of it. The elevators take you up to the 33rd floor, where you enter a different world. The lobby space, which also includes the bar and the restaurant, is really great with a ceiling reaching several stories up and an amazing view of the city. The surrounding is minimal and Japanese. Our room had the same great view. We were at the side of the building that you wake up in the morning and you see Mt. Fuji, if the weather permits. This was a nice treat! The room and the facilities are great. The spa and the pool are top notch. We had a chance to use both. At the spa, I explained an injury I had and they really personalized the “treatment”. The staff overall was extremely polite, and accommodating. One day in the early morning, like 6 am, I went out running, by the time I was back, they made sure that there was water and a towel right at the entrance of the hotel. I know that they have always water available, but it appeared that they made sure that this day was in place by the time I came back as it was not there when I left. The food at the restaurant both for dinner and breakfast were very good quality and with good variety. So, overall, we had a great stay and we would go back again. If I had to compare it with other hotel, it is right there on the top. If I had to compare it with other AMAN resorts, like the AMANs in Bali for example, there is a feeling of exclusivity and extreme pampering that you get in the resorts than is not there in the AMAN hotel.

I go to Tokyo every summer to attend to family business. Usually, I stay at the Peninsula as I love it's location and service. This year, when I heard the Aman had opened, I decided to split my time between the two hotels. I'm torn as to which one I like better as each one has it's strong and weak points.The Peninsula's location can't be beat. It's right by the Imperial Palace. Since I run every morning during my stay, being near the park is essential. After my 4:30 am run, I usually stop by the gym. The hotel has figured out how to allow 24 hour access to the gym with no extra effort and has a small moderately equipped gym that is always way to hot but it is well stocked with cold water and fruit. The Aman also allows 24 hour access to the gym but, in order to access the gym, you have to go to the front desk on the 33rd floor, ask for access, go back to the 34th floor, wait for them to unlock the gate then take another elevator back down to the 33rd floor. Way too much work at 4:30 am!Breakfast at the Peninsula is fine. With the breakfast package, you get a juice, coffee/tea, eggs and meat and pastries. At the Aman, breakfast is a feast! Three shots of juice (their green juice is amazing- the best I have ever had), fruit juice, coffee/tea, fruit platter, yogurt, pastry basket, eggs and meat! I was stuffed.The rooms are nice at both hotels, though different in decor. The separate dressing room and bedroom door at the Peninsula are helpful as is the master controller that includes a clock (essential) and temperature. They also have nice touches like plastic bags for your wet clothes and terry robes and yukatas (lightweight cotton kimono like robes). Fresh fruit and water is given every day.The Aman has fabulous views from their rooms and an amazing Japanese bathtub. The complimentary water and sodas are much appreciated and a standard amenity at all Amans.Customer service is unparalleled at The Aman. After I checked in (which takes a little time as they made me wait 10 minutes before someone came to check me in), all of the staff knew my name and would greet me as they saw me. At The Aman, breakfast service was fast and efficient. I was seated immediately and served shortly after. They were extremely accommodating and, at my request, made a few changes to their set menu. Upon check out, they had a taxi waiting for me and the bell staff waited until I pulled away to wave goodbye.At The Peninsula, the service is pleasant but more impersonal . Every morning, I had to wait for several minutes before I was acknowledged and seated. Once my order was taken and breakfast served, my server disappeared. People forgot to refill my water and I had to flag someone down in order to sign out. Pros and cons to each hotel- undecided as to where I will stay next year.

Great views, amazing pool, very well situated and typical first class quality. Service was also particularly good and helpful. Great first stay. Going back next week. Only tip is the restaurant gets booked up so make reservations if you want to eat in.

As soon as you arrive on the 33rd floor of the Otemachi Tower, the time stops. The beautiful, huge, super high ceiling, lobby of the Aman Hotel is zen, peaceful and full of light. The staff is welcoming, the rooms are nicely designed and huge (the "standard" room, called Deluxe room is 71m², the biggest in Tokyo). The (black) swimming pool is very big, with amazing views. The afternoon tea at the Lounge, although on the expensive side (more than 5000 yens per person you you have added the VAT), is exquisite: savory treats, crazy chocolate and other sweet creations as well as delicious scones. The tea and coffee selection is great and you can enjoy as many as you want. I fully recommend this afternoon tea as as treat!

Okay. When you are in a busy city like Tokyo, you want things done efficiently. So when I arrived at the hotel, I was quite frustrated that the check in process was awfully slow. I was asked to sit down in a lobby lounge and served a strange green tea based beverage but being told just to wait. 5 to 10 minutes later, the receptionist approached me and took me on a tour around the restaurant, cigar lounge, spa, and then finally to the room. From the time of arrival, it probably took more than half an hour to get to my room. This is their style, I understand, I should have known better. Nonetheless, felt like my time was wasted. Otherwise though, the hardware is just fantastic! The space, quietness.....just amazing. Staff are lovely, eager to please, but a bit slow. Not fully functional yet in my opinion. Restaurant food was disappointing. The sashimi was of low quality.Breakfast was lovely.At double the market rate, it is hard to justify to stay here however, considering the space and the quietness, I was thinking it may not be such an awful deal after all.Definitely not for everyone although the place is jar dropping gorgeous at night for everybody.
