review_body: We arrived from Kyoto at around 10 pm and check in took a bit of time. After that we were escorted to our room and it was one of the nicest Aman room we've been into. The hotel amenities really is one of the nicest one we've seen. Sunset drinks at the lobby was a surreal Tokyo experience and it was one of those quiet luxury moment that we loved. We really enjoyed our stay at Aman Tokyo and would definitely comeback if we've a chance.

The hotel is beautiful, minimalist in its approach. From the moment you walk in to the second you leave, the staff were so welcoming and it was sad to say good bye. Traveled for the first time as a family with my baby boy in tow, the staff spared not a single smile in ensuring his needs were met, from his baby food to even entertaining him while they hailed a cab, wow. Aman Tokyo is great for foodies too with Kitchen Street a hop, skip, and a stone throw away, Ippudo Ramen around the corner, it was wonderful. Shopping destinations like Harajuku were a 15min cab ride (watch out its 3500 yen a trip) or 140 yen per person on the metro (which in hindsight would have been a good experience if we weren't in a hurry). Will definitely stay here again.

This hotel is sterile and unwelcoming. The poor location means you can't walk around the area, a taxi is required.The suites look like a prison (with better sheets and beautiful wood panels) and the bucket next to the bath adds to the prison decor.Getting a glass of ordinary Champagne at the bar takes 22 minutes and costs about $30. It takes an age to walk around the hotel. What can I recommend: the views are beautiful, the tea in the rooms are nice. Comfortable beds.... but you can have all this and more in any Tokyo hotel for half the price.I recommend Grand Hyatt, Ritz Carlton or Capitol Tokyu over Aman Hotel - and they are much more reasonably priced.

Had a lovely relaxing two nights stay here. The hotel is beautiful, embracing both traditional designs but also as high tech as any hotel you would encounter in this futuristic city. The lobby has dramatic 30 meters cathedral like ceilings, everywhere there are multiple textures & tones, even my sleek entry level room was stunning, with expansive ceiling to floor windows in the living and bath area, the minimalist zen room was separated by traditional sliding doors, the bathroom had a traditional stone bath tub and what felt like heated floors. The view was of the imperial palace and gardens, though being a few blocks away, would imagine the view from the Palace hotel is even more impressive. I was only here for two nights so didn't have a chance to try out the restaurant or spa, did meet up with friends for drinks in the bar area and they were just as impressed with the atmospheric lobby. Overall it was a typical Aman stay with good service from the staff, restaurants' directions were printed out with maps in Japanese for taxi drivers, decor was local yet elegant and understated, the room was immaculate, quiet, flooded with light (loved it) & comfortable, quiet location on top of a subway and walking distance to Ginza etc. Only question in my mind was that I am used to paying Aman prices to try remote or exotic destinations, and used to the very charming & friendly service, here Aman felt like a fantastic city hotel (but not as intimate & efficient as other Amans ie I sent an email requesting three restaurant reservations on 5/15, on 5/16 the transporation staff contacted me re: airport transfers but it was only on 5/19 that concierge 1st emailed me back) ... when I can book ie Mandarin Oriental, the Peninsula etc (using our corporate rates) @ 1/3 of Aman Tokyo, not sure whether I would come back....

I have travelled extensively all over the world: this hotel is unconditionally the best hotel I have ever stayed at. It may very well not be for every one's taste, as the look and feel here is very much minimalism and it is meant to be quiet and tranquil. You come here for secluded luxury in the heart of one of the world's biggest cities. Don't come for buzz or crowds or gold fittings and crystal chandeliers. The main lobby on the 33rd floor is just simply breath taking. Five story high atrium, Japanese zen gardens in the middle, black volcanic stone on the walls, spectacular views of the city.Our room was amazing. Corner suite. Huge size. Incredible views of the imperial palace grounds and looking south towards Tokyo station. The hotel is brand new - rooms are in perfect condition. Electronic blinds and curtains, electronic lighting controls everywhere. Lots of storage space. Desk/study area. Two toilets. Spectacular walk in shower and bath, with views of the city.We had breakfast in our room every morning. The food was excellent and delivered EXACTLY at the time requested, every time.Service is outstanding. Staff were very friendly and attentive and went out of their way to help, without being overbearing or intrusive. Concierge arranged all of our restaurant reservations for our whole stay in Tokyo. We stayed for four nights overall and the whole thing was just simply perfection. I would very highly recommend, if you like minimalism, views, and peace/quiet/secluded environments.

The Hotel at first glance strikes you with temporary tranquility and charm But as i settled & sinked in , the effect started to diminish this ambiance goes well in a temple , but not a hotel It's depressing and feels like you're at a funeral , perhaps Gothic as one Reviewer rightfully described The Rooms are ok , minimalist design with nice panoramic view , they're huge ... At 70sqm for their lowest category but then does it justify pricing it almost equivalently to a suite at the Peninsula , Shangrilla , Mandarin Oriental , Four seasons and the Ritz ? having stayed at all of them , at this price I'd opt instead for a suite any of these hotels any given anytime , so Aman hasnt any advantage nor edge While the biggest Hurdle is The locations inconvenience, all the taxi's would drop you at the otomatchi office building instead , despite showing them location map Overall From where I stand I do not see myself coming back , nor do I see it out there with Tokyo's best , it's well behind .

A true sanctuary in the heart of Tokyo, with ultra privacy and unobstructed views from frameless glass in the bedroom to the lobby and pool. Interior is very refined with one of the most comfortable bedrooms I've ever stayed in. Flawless amenities and very low levels of sounds incl the aircon. A very slight complaint maybe is the blue light switches that are bright when everything else is off. Service is supreme and spa treatment is sumptuous. It sets the Amans on an urban scene without intentionally trying to be an 'urban resort' which is something pretentious and unrealistic.

It is by fare the best hotel I ever went to as the room and the service is concern. They go out of their way to please you.We normally go to Four Seasons, ritz, st Regis hotels around the world. This one beats all of them.Also they offer a tour call Kamakura Legacy tour. It is expensive but highly recommended. You will leave a unique experience.The only bad note is the food at the restaurant.

This hotel was fantastic, and a great place to stay for our first trip to Japan. We took the Express train from Narita Int'l Airport to Tokyo Station. We only had carry-on luggage, so we walked to the hotel, as it is only 5 minutes on foot via Tokyo Station. The staff were all pleasant and fluent in English. The lobby is spacious and filled with (super) dressed-up people sipping tea, which was sort of intimidating for us hayseeds in our Nikes. The rooms were superb--blond chestnut flooring, ridiculously massive bed (it had to be larger than a standard king), and dark stone bathroom equipped with $7,000 USD toilets--heated seats, customizable bidet action, dual flush, automatic sensors that lift the seat when you walk in during the middle of the night, the whole nine yards. We would learn that these toilets are not uncommon in Tokyo, but they blew my mind.The only meal we ate at the Aman Tokyo was a breakfast, which was high quality and reasonably priced. The fruit platter was excellent. The coffee was pretty good, but there is also a Dean & Deluca next door to the hotel.The location of the hotel was great. We were worried that we would be stuck in a business-centric part of town, and while the nearby streets were definitely filled with suits, there were many activities for tourists in the surrounding area (including shopping and dining options). I don't know what else to say beyond that. It checks off every box on the list: it is cool and exciting while still being calm and quiet, it is really, really fancy without being stuffy. it would be ideal for business travelers, as it is centrally located and very modern with many amenities. It is also perfect for leisure travelers (couples, families, or otherwise), and the rooms are decorated in a distinctively Japanese way, which made it way more fun than staying in the rooms at the Ritz or Mandarin, which looked sterile and unimaginative in comparison (on internet photos, at least). this was our 2nd stay at an Aman and my family and I are completely sold

review_body: Without a doubt one of the finest hotels in the world and they just opened. I have never had a more comfortable room. The lobby is stunning. The design is jaw dropping gorgeous. The service is sincere.Many hotels make you feel like a valued customer but few make you feel like a true guest.Bravo Aman Bravo

I will not add to the brilliant and accurate descriptions below of this wonderful hotel, but will use my time to describe the one niggle we had with the service.My husband and I are big foodies and shot out reservation requests to the Aman concierge and the concierge of the other hotels we enjoyed during our stay in Tokyo. The Aman concierge did not reply for a week - we sent repeated emails and finally got a reply after an email of complaint. Once we made contact with the concierge the overall tone of the exchange was warm and very enjoyable, so we requested they look in to some Sumo tickets for us. Tickets could only be secured for a day we were staying at another hotel - so they recommended we ask that concierge! Not as accommodating as we expected, and a bit of a disappointment given the price point. Both Mandarin Oriental and Park Hyatt much more satisfying in this area.Make sure you enjoy the pool and spa areas, which miraculously do provide the illusion of a resort in the huge metropolis that is Tokyo.

My interior designer wife and I arrived in Tokyo from london bleary eyed and in a dismaying state of jet lag, and the staff of the Aman nursed us back into peaceful contentment even though we arrived well before check in (around 11am). The first reception downstairs was a helpful addition and made us feel welcome even before we entered the magnificent lobby. My wife is rarely overwhelmed by hotel design but the enormous lantern ceiling and interior garden to compliment the full length windows running along 3 sides both impressed and gave a sense of intense well-being. We were ushered smoothly to the spa for a treatment before relaxing beside the pool, and what a pool! I believe it to be the longest hotel pool in Tokyo and the beds flanking the water were a delightful spot to rest before we completed check in. The staff remained constantly smiling and helpful at the slightest bidding, and never made us feel demanding.Our entry level room was no less magnificent for not being a suite, and had expansive views of the imperial gardens from both bed area and the bathroom. The use of dark stone throughout the hotel and room is extremely consistent, and the camphor wood and bath evoke the traditional qualities of Japan in a luxurious setting. Every aspect of the room has been thought through with great care and attention including global plug sockets by the bed, room for a desk both behind the bed and at the window where you have a separate sitting and reclining area. The TV has been cleverly hidden to leave unobstructed views, while the sliding screens afford complete intimacy when your partner is in the bathroom. Light streams into every corner of the bedroom and mirrors are also artfully placed. Breakfast both continental and Japanese was delicious and prettily presented, and the waiters/waitresses were disarmingly sweet and hospitable with a genuine desire to help in every way. We encountered the same experience at lunch and dinner, and were impressed by our one italian dish tasted in Tokyo (my wife is italian hence picky) and the excellent choice of wines from the sommelier. I was hoping to try a number of exclusive and difficult to access restaurants in Tokyo and the senior concierge Cullen Ozaki and his team were of great assistance in making the trip special. No task was too great including the organisation of a private Iaido sword class, the perfect sushi experience at Sushi Tokami in Ginza and the booking of the train tickets for our next leg.We will without a doubt revisit the Aman, and it is one of the best romantic hotel experiences we have ever had.

Its a Nice Hotel.. extremely new (less than 4 Months Old)The lobby is Huge and grand (Yet ZEN)There is a nice Bar (Cigar Bar), and Restaurant.Rooms are nice and spacious, ZEN style,But the bed is not as comfy as like- Shang or Ritzs type.The type you feel like you are in sleeping on Clouds..Service is nice and personal... but still needs find tuning (I guess they are still new)Overall a nice Hotel... not the best of AMAN yet...

We stayed there March 2015 for four nights. The experience was so wonderful that while we were there we booked another stay for October. The design is otherworldly. When we first saw the lobby, we were left without words. I thought perhaps we had died on the shinkansen and were in the lobby of heaven. The 25 meter high volume is a giant glowing paper lantern. The rest of the hotel is clad in black basalt. There is a small zen garden in the middle. There was even someone playing the koto. Rarely, am I so moved by design. There are only about 85 rooms. Our corner suite was beautiful--understated and airy, with a large bathroom and soaking tub all in the same basalt, shoji screens, perfect bed, the list goes on. We had a killer view of Mt. Fuji. Even the hallways are perfectly done. We never saw a single outlet, cord, cleaning cart, etc. The spa and pool are fantastic. The service was impeccable. Shimizu-san, the lobby manager, is a gem. She'll help you with anything you need, and make you feel as if you're the only guests in the hotel. The only nit we had is that the bar staff was a little confused by simple drinks (Kettle One up with a twist was, for some reason, difficult). The restaurant was delicious, however, both for dinner and breakfast. All in all, it was one of the best Aman experiences we've had.

The Aman was good but not the best Aman. The staff were kind but were struggling with figuring out exactly what to do, maybe they will improve with time. They do not warn about nuts (I am allergic to pistachios) and on our last full day I become extremely sick because of the nuts. The hotel was very nice but its not great for a family. If you would like to go to an Aman I recommend Bali or Vietnam they are better.

We had a nice stay here. The design of the lobby, pool (Tokyo's longest...) and room were all impressive - we went for a deluxe (nearer to base category than a suite), but it was very large and had great views over the Imperial Palace. The bed was very comfortable. It may just be that it is early days, but we felt that a bit of the Aman magic was missing. The service wasn't quite as smooth as at other of their resorts we have stayed at.

Fantastic new hotel in Tokyo in a great location on the top floors of Otemachi Tower just a block from Tokyo station. Felt very private. Huge room was bigger than most Tokyo apartments. Gorgeous pool and spa. The staff to guest ratio is ridiculous, but you're paying for it. Food is excellent and reasonably priced. Would not hesitate to go again or recommend.

right from entering the lobby I knew something was wrong. The weird creepy goth design was sooo cold and unfriendly. The rooms were sterile and tried too hard to be Japanese minimalist. Staff was struggling to get it right. Would I go back? No. Tokyo is full of excellent hotels why subject yourself to somewhere so inhospitable?

My husband is taking me to Tokyo and Kyoto this year, as we've heard Aman just opened their first city property ever (didn't they have an Aman in New Delhi and it got sold or something...?). We were very pleasantly surprised when the elevator door opened, we were greeted by staff of Amandari and Amanjiwo, as they were in Tokyo to organize/help out with the grand opening of Aman Tokyo. It was wonderful that the Amandari & Amanjiwo remembered us from our previous stay at both properties (but of course they do, this is an Aman experience!).We stayed at one of their Suites, initially we wanted a room with Mt Fuji room, but were informed only standard and corner rooms have the view. We requested Tokyo SkyTree view instead and it's an amazing view! The Suite was lovely, very zen and very large for a Tokyo hotel room.Service was very good of course, but obviously as a new property it can be polished further to be on the same level as the rest of Aman resorts in SE Asia. Also as a new Aman, they only had 2 Aman activities to offer, a rickshaw ride or a trip to Tsujiki fish market with one of Aman chefs.Our stay was indeed a lovely experience and we were informed 2 more Amans are in the works for Japan, including Kyoto! We highly recommend staying in Aman Tokyo.

This hotel is much more impressive in person than in website photos. I thought I might be disappointed, but walking into the lobby the first time (and each time after) was very impressive. We were given a quick tour by the lobby manager before being shown to our room, and you will be awestruck by the view from your room as well as the elegance and simplicity of the decor. All the shoji doors were shut at first, but then opening up the doors reveals a fantastic bath/wet area in the bedroom and then a hidden work desk and half bath behind the shoji doors in the living area. We were first given a room facing north (view of Sky Tree) which was a little noisy due to nearby construction (serious earth-drilling activity) but were comfortably moved to a south facing room with views of Tokyo Tower, Palace, Rainbow Bridge/Tokyo Bay, Odaiba, Haneda and Mt Fuji. Our room had much of a city apartment living feel, including a dishwasher. The room has very effective blackout drapes, but an issue I have with many hotels with all the fancy control buttons is the bright lights that stay illuminated on the buttons all night.The hotel is a short walk from Tokyo Station and can be accessed completely underground. There is a bit of construction but we went towards B1 exit and Ootemori signs to get to the hotel via underground. Hotel signage is not that obvious from street level. There are maps around that mark Otemachi Tower and Mizuho, and seeing pictures of the building helps identify too.There isn't much that is eco about the hotel. Some tree-huggers might be upset by that. Used towels were replaced twice a day, soap was replaced every other day it seemed. Breakfast set menus are enormous. There is western and Jpns options with ingredients sourced throughout Japan. The pool is beautiful, towering ceilings. It is 30m long and 25m long from stair entry to stair entry (so there is one end to swim 30m lengths). The pool is about 31deg C (88deg F) which is a tad warm for laps. One of my biggest pet peeves is when people don't rinse before entering the pool, so there were a few times where I could taste people's perfume in the water when they entered. Disgusting. There is a shower poolside, please rinse thoroughly before entering the pool. The gym has standard hotel cardio and machines, plus a rower and pullup cage, studios for yoga and pilates (most equipment except the Cadillac). Swim and exercise gear can be borrowed from locker room attendant. The spa has great bath facilities including steam, hot bath and cold water rinse. The first day I asked about a swimsuit spin/dryer and a couple days later they had one installed! The spa treatments are very nice (and expensive) and in a room with natural light, so they're not in a dark corner like most typical treatment rooms. There were some very minor kinks before and during our stay which is probably just part of getting started. There were staff from different Aman properties during our visit to help with the soft opening. We bounce around to different hotels each time we visit Tokyo, but it might be hard to top Aman, even with the upcoming St Regis and Hoshinoya properties. The hotel lobby was never really busy or buzzing at the bar. I'm not sure if that's the intent, but it definitely has a remote resort feeling. We didn't really leave the hotel much except for lunch and dinner. It's a very relaxing and pampering setting.

We loved our stay at the Aman Tokyo. The bed was insanely comfortable, the views sensational. The staff was very warm. We stayed there during their 'soft opening,' and got the sense that so far, it's geared more towards businessmen than it is towards tourists. However, we still had a really great time. An absolute MUST DO is the journey to the Tsukiji Fish Market with Chef Oba + dinner at his sushi restaurant. It was the best meal either of us have ever had, and Chef Oba is a delight to spend time with. We were a little disappointed with the lack of Japanese food on their menu -- though I'm sure that's something they'll likely sort out in due time. The swimming pool is great, as is the spa. Both my husband and I thought our massages were excellent. Great hotel, a few kinks to work out, but they've managed to do a great job keeping the tranquility of the resort feel in an urban setting. Would definitely go back again!

review_body: Very warm and nice welcome with a nice touch of japanese discretion The bar is a very nice place for a drink to see sunset on fuji-san. The swimming pool is magic to use early morning with and amaizing view on midtown buildings.

Cut to the chase: this is the hotel I most look forward to re-visiting, in the world. I've been to the Aman resorts in Bali so I was naturally curious to see how they'd pull off a hotel in the most urban setting possible. Well it's stunning and the execution of the staff is nearly perfect in spite of only being open to the public for 6 weeks. The hotel did an excellent job of getting my arrival details arranged but I was traveling lightly wanted to walk from Tokyo Station (having arrived from Narita) to the hotel. They suggested, with good reason, that a taxi would have been the preferred mode, for arriving in the evening. The hotel itself is difficult to find in the dark even though it's a 3 block walk. The signage is much more visible in the daylight. Having found the building, Aman took over and escorted me every step of the way through the checkin process. The lobby on the 33rd floor is a jaw-dropper and photographs do nothing to describe what it's like in person. The ceiling opens up several floors, covered in japanese paper in a huge space. The whole effect is dark stone, white paper and abundant wood. I had booked the deluxe room (entry level) because of the view towards the Imperial Palace. The room was very large by any standard (70+ sq m) and the space was put to excellent use. Like the lobby, the room is stone, wood and white paper. The Aman Tokyo design concepts are sparse and have been called zen-like. For me this was flawlessly executed. For others, if this style doesn't resonate, then this is NOT the hotel to stay in. The minimal design ethic is implemented throughout the room, the bath and the sitting area facing the window. Everything is automated, including the toilet (as is standard in Japan.) I had breakfast twice in the lobby, once western-style and once Japanese style. Again the execution of the staff was perfect and the meals were excellent. On checkout, I was heading to Kyoto via Shinkansen and the staff arranged transport back to the Tokyo Station and had an assistant help me purchase tickets. My bags had custom Aman luggage tags with my name printed, a very nice touch. Hotel quality in Tokyo is very, very high indeed and having stayed at the Four Seasons, The Ritz Carlton, and the Park Hyatt, I would certainly put the Aman at the top of that list; not only in Tokyo but world-wide.

An amazing property currently in a sort of pre opening before official launch; and a long anticipated first for Aman in that it is the only urban property within their portfolio.The pictures will never do it full justice and the impact of walking into a 3 story high lobby , on the 33rd floor of the Otemachi Tower is simply breathtaking. Views from the lounge and restaurant are over the Imperial Palace and Gardens and to Mouth Fuji and beyond.Staff are exceptionally service focussed and Kullen-San the Concierge has to be one of the best in town, with the ability to arrange money can't buy experiences and personal tours throughout the city , including a 5am tour of the famous fish market and Tuna auction.
